There would be a letter to write to a boy in Dunedin who wanted to know how to bake without waking his father. There would be a shopping list for butter and lemons and the green cord that goes on the gazebo that always disappears, and a call to Tasi to ask if the new sound Cherry was making was a joke or a threat. There would be all the small practical magic that keeps a life from coming apart at its seams. For now, the room put its hand on my back and moved me where I needed to be. For now, the biscuits cooled. For now, the gull shrieked two notes that didn’t sound like my name and I decided I didn’t mind.

The morning the gulls learned my name, the Auckland sky was the colour of cold butter, and my kitchen window had the kind of condensation that makes everything beyond it blur into a kinder world. Steam curled from the pot where passionfruit pulp simmered and popped; a yellow riot turning itself into curd while the radio whispered news about delays on the motorway and a ferry that had left without someone important on it. I hummed a few bars of something I didn’t know, tapping my spoon against the lip of the saucepan—one, two, three—and then checked the temperature again as if I could will it into place by staring.

The stove ran slightly hot, a fact that mattered to me more than it should. The curd thickened like it had been waiting for my attention all along, so I drew the pot off the heat and whisked in the butter. It was a slow bright spell of stirring, the kind that holds my head above water. I had a feeling the gulls across the street could smell sugar when the day was still deciding itself. They shrieked and flapped past the lamppost where flyers curled damply, where kids had taped an ad for a missing skateboard and a flatmate who didn’t mind cats.

My flatmate, Kahu, padded in barefoot, hair springing into the sort of halo that defies gravity and fashion. He stretched, yawned, then flinched theatrically as the smell hit him.

“Damn, Nia, that’s criminal,” he said. “You’re going to anger the weather gods with something that good this early.”

“Let them come,” I said, and tried not to grin. “Want some on toast?”

“I shouldn’t. I absolutely should.” He held out a plate, and I swiped a spoonful of curd onto the heel of a slice. He bit it, eyes rolling back. “Killer. Sweet as. What’s the occasion? Don’t tell me—just a Wednesday.”

“It’s a Tuesday,” I said. “And I’ve got a plan.”

“Oh, there it is. The twinkle.” He leaned against the benchtop, cocked a hip. “Is this plan called ‘inventing breakfast’ or ‘beating a bunch of very nice television people with your whisk’?”

Heat crept up my neck. I liked that my friends were merciless; I liked it more than anything, in secret. “Both. Neither,” I said. “Mrs. Healy is coming down from the hospice this afternoon. She claims to be bringing coconut.”

“Your hospice gang is more exciting than my thesis committee.”

“Everyone’s more exciting than your thesis committee.” I scraped the last of the curd into a jar and pressed clingfilm onto its skin. Across the street, the gulls played something that sounded like laughter. “Did your car start this morning?”

“For now,” he said, wincing. “She coughed like a chain-smoker but she got there. I’m taking her to Tasi this week. He’ll yell at her and she’ll straighten herself out, like me after my mother rings.”

“Tasi is a miracle worker,” I said. “Cherry could use a stern talking-to as well.”

Cherry was not so much a car as a stubborn red blister on wheels, a 2002 Mazda with a cracked dashboard and a temper. The back left window didn’t roll down anymore, the radio sometimes sang only in static, and the passenger door required you to push it with both hands to close. But she had been mine since the summer I turned nineteen and scraped together enough from coffee shop tips and selling muffins at the markets, so maybe she lived on out of pure loyalty.

“You’re taking Cherry to Tasi, too?” Kahu asked. “When’s your next shoot? You told me yesterday and I forget. My brain is oatmeal.”

“No shoots,” I said, though my voice didn’t sound like mine for half a breath. “There’s no next. I mean—there is. But not like that. I’m waiting.”

“Waiting,” he repeated, drawing the word into something silly and significant. “For a call.”

“For an email,” I said. “They always email before they call.”

“And do you have your phone volume up? Because if it’s not loud enough, the email fairies can’t get through.”

“Funny.”

“Do you have that lucky spoon you said you would never ever wash again?”

“Washed it last night,” I admitted. “Accidents happen.”

He put a hand to his chest. “You’re a braver woman than I. Okay, I’m off to prostrate myself in front of the gods of grading. Kai later?”

“Later,” I said, and listened to him throw a hoodie over his head, trip on the mat at the door, bark a laugh at himself, and gone. The apartment exhaled with him. The curd cooled. The radio man said something about a painter whose works were found in a thrift store for three dollars. The day began again.

When my phone chimed—just an email, just a ping—the spoon in my hand knocked the counter. It was ridiculous, the freefall in my chest, the way the world narrowed to a crackling rectangle of glass. The sender line said what I knew it would: Production. The subject line was as simple as a heartbeat.

We would love to see you in the final, if you’re willing.

I had not known how much I was braced for a different sentence until then. I read it once, twice, a dozen times; I read it out loud to the kettle, to the sticky ring of sugar on the stovetop. The little black letters did not rearrange themselves into anything else. They were themselves, which meant I was a person standing in a crumby kitchen in Mount Roskill who had just been asked to step inside a white tent where flour behaved like confetti and somebody’s grandmother was watching me through a television screen, thinking, Girl, try the lemon zest.

I pressed my palms flat on the counter as if I could steady the world by pinning it down. My phone chimed again: a follow-up with the schedule, the list of requirements, the little hiragana of what lenses we were on and what we were to bring. And there, at the end, as casual as you like: Please drive to the location by 6:45 a.m. sharp. Directions attached.

I laughed, the kind that noses against a sob. “You can’t make me,” I told the email. “You can and you did.”

I should have called Kahu back but picked Lena instead. She was at the café in Eden Terrace by seven most days; we’d worked together for years and held each other up through long shifts, through the summer a pipe burst and turned our backroom into a swamp, through my first episode where my hands shook so hard I thought the camera would catch me out. She answered on the second ring.

“Nia. I was about to burn a batch of banana bread for you. You stopped me in the nick of time.”

“You always put too much cinnamon in it,” I said.

“That’s slander. You love my cinnamon. What’s wrong? Your voice is strange.”

“They emailed,” I said, and the smile split my face. “They want me in the final.”

There was a noise in my ear that could have been Lena squealing or the coffee machine pitching a fit. “You—what—holy—Nia. Oh my god. I knew it. I knew it. Of course. You’re gonna be on the telly again, in the last one? The big one? Do you need me to come over there and fan you with a baking sheet?”

“Gas oven tray,” I said, breathless. “Kahu says it has more surface area.”

“Listen to Kahu, he’s wise. I’m making a chocolate roulade right this second and it’s going to dance for you. And you’re going to make—what are you going to make? You can’t tell me, can you. Because they’ll sue you.”

“I can tell you some. They want a showstopper that tells a story,” I said softly, like speaking it could shatter it. “And a technical where we all cry. And a signature where I’ll probably cut myself and pretend like I meant to. Or burn the sugar into a new element.”

“You always say that and then you pull something out of yourself like it’s been there since you were small.”

I was small once, smaller than I like to admit. In those days, before I knew proper ovens or the name for a soft peak or the patience to wait for butter to soften on its own, I baked in microwaves, in toaster ovens, in a cracked communal oven that devoured cookies and spit out grit with a grin. The home in Avondale had six of us then: two girls who braided my hair too tight, a boy who spoke only in hotspots of silence, a couple who loved each other in a way that made the whole house tilt. Renee was the house manager, a woman with hands that never stopped moving. She baked the way my mother might have—I never knew; I don’t guess out loud—but there were scones that made everything warmer than it had been before.

“I’ll make something for her,” I said now, into Lena’s ear and also into the bigger listening space my life had become. “For Renee. For me. There’ll be feijoa. Everyone will hate it except me.”

“Everyone loves feijoa, shut up. I’ll start stockpiling fruit. Hey. Proud of you. Proper proud. I’d hug you but that would involve leaving the machine and then the world might stop, so I’ll hold it for later.”

The world did not stop. It changed angles. I poured coffee into the chipped mug with the fading picture of the Sky Tower, the one I’d rescued from a box at the community centre because it felt like a talisman against the bigness of the city and the ache of being alone in it. I set the mug next to the jar of curd and, like a madwoman, opened the email again. They were filming the final in a vineyard outside Matakana. I knew the place; we’d driven past on a school trip once, the vines held in neat tight rows like someone who had smoothed a hand over the earth. It would mean taking the motorway north, past Onewa Road where the trees showed their roots after a storm, the bridge arching like it was used to carrying much heavier stories than me. I tried to picture Cherry making it, her laugh of an engine keeping up. I could do it. I had done much harder things. Right?

Right, I told myself, and the word had a wobble.

By midday I had told the people who would either show up with flowers or with the right kind of silence. Kahu blew me a kiss from the doorframe; Lena sent a picture of herself holding a piping bag like a dagger. Mrs. Healy messaged a long row of heart emojis that looked like a flock of odd birds. I made lunch I could not taste and, later, went to the hospice with two boxes: one for the staff, one for the women who helped me understand grief as a kind of second language. The hospice smelled like lemon hand gel and hope. The windows framed an ordinary blue day that seemed aware of itself, and the kitchen was blessedly empty save for the low hum of an overfed fridge.

“Hallo, sweetheart,” said Mrs. Healy, coming in with her stick thumping politely. She was tall and sharp and would not have looked out of place warning sailors about rocks. “You’ve brought sun.”

“Just curd,” I said, and set the jar on the counter like an offering. “And some little shortbreads. How are you?”

“Full of mischief and pills,” she said. “I went hard at physiotherapy and now I can raise my arm like this.” She lifted it to shoulder height and winced with triumph. “Tonight I will reach a little higher. And you?”

“They asked me to be in the final,” I said. The words had begun to fit my mouth.

She peered at me over the top of her glasses. “My pretty girl,” she said, satisfied. “Of course they did.”

“Mrs. Healy—”

“I know, I know, looks aren’t everything, but a pretty girl is a girl who is loved. And you are that now.”

“I wasn’t always.”

“What you are now is what you are,” she said, in a voice that belonged to both our mothers. She reached out and pinched my cheek, very lightly. “You are going to make those judges weep. Are you bringing your notebook? Are you bringing a plan? Are you going to remember to eat? Don’t get thin on me. You always try to get thin when you get nervous.”

“I never try,” I said. “It happens by accident. But I brought two sandwiches today.”

“Smart,” she said, clearly pleased. Then softer: “I won’t see it, you know. You’ll have to tell me. When they announce it, when you stand there, give me the story. You’re my eyes.”

I swallowed. We didn’t say the rest aloud. Coco, the nurse with lavender on her wrists, drifted in and leaned against the counter, eyes bright.

“Is it true? Did you make it?” she asked me. “Lily said she saw you in the paper last week and they were calling you ‘our Auckland hopeful’. I told her, Nah, she’s our hopeful.”

I laughed. “It’s true. I made it.”

“Girl, you’re going to be world famous in Ponsonby,” Coco said. “Put me down for a pack of your biscotti now. When you get your own bakery and you forget the rest of us, I’m going to show up with this spoon and bang on the window.”

“I’ll give you a key,” I said. “And your own seat.”

It was a good afternoon. The ladies of the Tuesday knitting group tasted the curd with the reverence given to manna and then critiqued it with the ferocity given to injustice. Too sharp, said Nora; not sharp enough, said Lily; just right, said Mrs. Healy, because she knew when to back me and when to push. I brought out a second jar and a third, things I had not planned to make but somehow had on hand because that’s the sort of person I am when I’m afraid. We talked recipes and pronkt with the yarn, all of it, and when I walked back into the slightly cooler evening, my heart had found a place to stand where it didn’t shake.

On the way home, Cherry rattled like someone with a secret. At the lights on Dominion Road, she coughed once, then twice, like a warning. I patted the steering wheel and talked to her like a horse. “Not yet,” I said. “Wait for me. I’m almost there.”

The email had attached directions to the vineyard; I printed them at the library, because paper settles me, because the act of folding it twice and tucking it beneath a magnet on my fridge made the world real. I put asterisks next to the lines about showstopper notes and labelled plastic containers. I wrote a list on the back:

- candied feijoa peel
- puff pastry test batch #3
- new piping nozzles, maybe the leaf one?
- call Tasi for cherry

I wrote cherry, lowercase, like a fruit. Then I crossed it out and wrote Cherry, like a promise.

I practiced. I practiced until the apartment smelled like sugar, burned and redeemed, until the floor was a white map of mistakes, until my fingers were blistered from the whisk and I was talking to myself, which is to say, I was talking to Renee. She used to say, “It’s all in the wrist, baby,” and “Don’t you dare throw that batch away—there are no saints who aren’t sinners first,” and I could hear her voice now—smoke(d) and honey—holding up the edges of me. I made a rough sketch of a croquembouche disguised as a pohutukawa tree, then threw the sketch away on account of madness. I test-drove a lamington sponge so light it forgave me for everything I’d done to it. I folded feijoa into cream and sugar and the memory of summer. When the curd ran away from me, I coaxed it back. When the caramel seized, I ignored the camera in my head and swore, quietly, then louder, then with relief.

On the third day, with my kitchen turned into a full armed conflict between flour and sanity, Kahu stuck his head around the door, blinked, and said, “Ever thought of opening an industrial bakery and moving your bed in there?”

“It’s an option,” I said, hair anchored with a tea towel. “I’m making four things at once. It’s going to be fine.”

“Is that a lie or a sacred chant.”

“Yes,” I said, and then, because he looked at me gently, I let the secret out. “Sometimes I think, if I win, it changes everything. And if I don’t, it changes nothing. And both of those are frightening.”

Kahu came in, stepping around a saucepan like it was a small animal with teeth. “Tell me your other fear, the one you’re not saying,” he said.

I ran water over my fingers, watched the sugar dissolve. “Driving,” I said. “On the day. It’ll be early. There’s the bridge, and the motorway, and the thought keeps gnawing. What if Cherry decides to throw a fit. What if I’m late and they throw me out and that’s the story I tell for the rest of my life.”

“You’ll be early,” he said, like it was a blessing. “We’ll take Cherry to Tasi on Friday. He’ll do the thing with the screwdriver and the swearing, and she’ll purr. Don’t look at me like that. Trust him.”

“I do,” I said. “I just—money.”

“We’ll figure it out,” he said. “I’ve got a little. You’ve got a lot of cake. We’ll start a black market in shortbread. Also, I know your secret fans. They’ll pay whatever you tell them to.”

“I have fans,” I said, and we laughed until it was true.

Later, alone, I stood at the sink with the window open to the evening and watched a bus hum past, yellow seats bobbing with passengers. A couple on the sidewalk argued softly but kept their hands stitched together by a finger. The sky went belly-up salmon pink. I had the impulse to call Jules, which scared me because of what it meant. Jules had been in the tent with me once, early, the episode where we made things that melted if you looked at them sideways. They were from Christchurch, they wore bracelets their little sister had made, and they had a way of swearing with tenderness that settled me down. We had not been allowed to be friends in the way that lasts; rules and timing stole that from us. But after the episode aired, we’d called anyway. And then sometimes, when the weight lay across my chest like a cat refusing to move, I’d call and they’d pick up and talk about nothing until it shifted.

I pressed their name with my thumb; when they answered, their voice landed in my ear like a hand on my arm.

“Hey, baker,” Jules said. “How’s the world of butter and tears?”

“They asked me to the final,” I said. It still felt like a dare when I said it.

“Because you’re obscene,” Jules said, without missing a beat. “I mean that in a nice way. Congratulations.”

“Thanks.” I shifted the phone to the other side. “I’m terrified I’ll mess the lamingtons. How embarrassing would that be.”

“So embarrassing,” they said solemnly. “I mean, you’d have to move to Australia. Witness protection. It’s over for you.”

I snorted. “Wow, thanks.”

“You’re going to make something that tastes like the first lemonade you ever drank in summer,” Jules said, gentler. “You’re going to be annoying about it. And then you’re going to call me afterward, and we’re going to debrief on who cried and what jokes the hosts made that didn’t land. And if you don’t win—listen to me now—if you don’t, we’re still going to do that. Okay?”

“Okay,” I said.

“You have your list?”

“Which one? I’ve got about seven.”

“The one with the practical shit. Petrol, spare tyre, snacks, Spotify playlist labelled ‘don’t cry on the bridge’.”

I looked at my fridge where a magnet held my paper life together. “Working on it.”

“Work faster,” they said. “You can control that. The rest—nope. That’s for ghosts and editors. You’re too alive for that.”

“Who told you to be this kind.”

“I’m a menace,” they said. “Go sleep. The secret is sleep.”

The secret had always been sleep, and there had always been not enough of it. I dreamed of butter melting in my hands and woke to my pillow being too warm. I put on old sneakers and ran down to the dairy on the corner in the dim half-light, bought milk and eggs and bananas and let Mr. Singh tell me about the cricket as if the score mattered to the sugar in my veins. On the way back, my phone buzzed again with a text from Production with more instructions and a caution about the early start and a reminder to bring ID and a smile. The smile I could do. The ID I could find. The rest of it, I would hold like a bowl full to the lip, steadying each move.

Friday came, and with it a sky like steel and the thin threat of rain. Kahu drove with me to Tasi’s garage in Sandringham, the one with the painted mural of a sea turtle on the roller door and a bench made from old tyres. Fa’amasino was his last name, Tasi what everyone called him because he was the first son and carried that with a grin that could turn a wrench. He had been fixing everyone’s car since the nineties and was the only person I’d ever seen talk a radiator into behaving.

“Ni sa bula, sis,” he said, when I rolled Cherry in. “She’s still red? Good. Red cars never quit, they just sulk.”

“She’s got a little cough,” I said. “She’s... I’ve got to drive to Matakana.”

He looked at me and then at the car and then at me again, and his eyebrows did the exact thing that meant he wasn’t going to make me feel bad about money. “We’ll make sure she sings,” he said. “Leave her with me. You go get a pie. You look like a broom.”

“Polite,” I told him. “Thank you. Don’t let her forget me.”

He patted the bonnet. “She knows your hand. Go on.”

We waited in the little office that smelled like oil and corrugated iron and coffee burned until it came good. There were magazines about boats and men in shorts, and a calendar with kittens in hard hats, and a sign that said No we do not fix computers. Kahu tapped a rhythm on the arm of the chair. I pretended to read worth less nothing of a brochure on windscreen replacements and watched the rain decide, then not decide, then fall.

Tasi came back out with a rag over his shoulder and a look that said he had found something and he wasn’t going to be alarmed about it. “Your girl’s got a worn belt and a battery keen to retire,” he said. “Needs tender love and a little cash. How deep’s your love?”

“I can do the belt,” I said, before I could stop myself, because poor and proud are cousins. “The battery—”

“You can’t bake on the side of the road,” he said, not unkind. “You need both. Lucky for you, I like lamingtons.”

“I’ll bring you six dozen,” I said.

“Three,” he said, smug. “And a loaf of whatever that bread is that smells like angels.”

“Brioche,” Kahu supplied. “She makes the price of property rise when she bakes it.”

“Consider it done,” I said.

We bartered until I felt stupid and then steady again. Tasi called me girl twice and sister once; it is the kind of love I can stand. I left Cherry there with a kiss to the steering wheel and walked home in the drizzle with Kahu’s umbrella handle hooked over my wrist. The day had a chill through it; the air smelled like rain on tarmac and damp jacaranda. My shoes squelched. A gull escorted us for a block and then gave up.

The apartment was a set of lists. I lay them out on the table and picked them up, one by one, like cards in a game where the stakes were not my life and also were. I placed bowls where I would want them, as if I could practice the final from a distance, as if my hands could learn without the heat or the eyes on them. The truth is, the tent had felt like home. I had flour on my lips and butter in my hair and a silly smile I couldn’t not wear, and the producers had moved like careful moths around us, trying not to startle anything. I had learned the rhythm of the jokes and the tap of the judges’ shoes. I had learned to breathe when the timer sounded like it was mocking me. I was ready—except for the parts of me that never would be. Which is to say: the parts of me that had lived through late nights counting chairs in the community centre to make rent; the parts of me that had sat in the kitchens of houses that were not mine and learned to wipe counters so I could stay; the parts of me that, when I am honest, still flinch at sudden kindness as if from a blow.

When I couldn’t bake anymore, I went down to the water. It was what I do when my head buzzes, when the city feels like a jar with the lid screwed on too tight. At Devonport, the wind tried to jam itself into my ears, and the sea held the shore in its mouth, and people who weren’t me walked past very alive. A couple took wedding photos and then looked like children who had been dressed up by their mothers. The ferry churned up a long ribbon of white that wrinkled the blue. I told the sea the same thing I always tell it: that I am small, that I am afraid of disappearing, that I am also, stubbornly, something like a woman made of eggs and sugar and heat.

When I got home, there was a note under my door, in a spidery hand that nearly fell off the page with the effort of being read:

Muffin girl—don’t make those fancy people forget where you came from. Make one thing that tastes like an afternoon on the back steps. And if you need a ride, say so. We don’t have to be proud all the time. —Mrs. Kline, 3B.

Mrs. Kline was ninety if she was a day and had a cat named Beethoven who hated everyone but me because once I fed him a little sliver of ham. She took the stairs one at a time and died in my nightmares, but for now she lived in a world where she crocheted covers for kettles and put her hand through my open window to leave me notes.

I put the note on my fridge next to the directions. In case of literal disaster, she had written, in smaller letters. Phone me.

Cherry came back to me the following afternoon, purring like a cat after cream. I drove her around the block and then around the next one and then as far as Onehunga and back just to feel the motor stretch, line by line. I filled her tank. I vacuumed the crumbs under the driver’s seat and found a bobby pin I’d lost and two dollars. I put a little square of old towel on the dashboard so I could rest my phone there for the directions, like a ninety-year-old, like the child I was. On the morning before the final, I put my hands on Cherry’s hood and said thank you, because I have learned to thank things I expect to hold me.

The last night before, I slept. Properly. The sort of sleep that arrives like a friend on a warm afternoon and insists you lie down on the couch with your feet tucked under and your eyes turned to a place where light leaks through your closed lids. Morning came cool and clean. I stood under the shower until the hot water sighed its last. I pulled on jeans and a T-shirt and a light jumper and tied my hair up and down three times and settled on up, because of cameras, because of the relentlessness of the wind at Matakana. I ate two slices of toast and half a banana and could not remember if either had tasted of anything. I checked my lists. I put the spare tyre on my list though it was already in the boot. I kissed the magnet that held the directions on my fridge and did a stupid little dance at the door because there was no one to see me and because my body needed to celebrate something, anything.

The city at five was not my city. It belonged to men in high-vis vests and women in quiet shoes walking dogs that glowed under the streetlights. The motorway sighed. The gulls were asleep. The radio played a song that promised me I was not alone and then forgot me immediately. I drove the way you do when you are not sure if you have permission; I touched my shoulder to check the seatbelt out of an old superstition; I whispered the names of exits like a prayer.

A few minutes before six, my phone vibrated on the towel where it sat. I glanced down. Production had texted: See you soon! Coffee is hot. The tent is a dream. Drive safe.

I put the phone face down. I breathed. I could do this. The bridge rose up ahead like a spine. The harbor unrolled itself like a sheet behind. I tightened my grip on the wheel until my knuckles had their own ideas, and I sang, badly, on purpose, the song my mother never sang me, the one that goes, You are your own home. I believed it. I tried to.

There were so many ways to tell this story. There was the version where I delivered on the promise of the girl in the paper. There was the version where I made small neat mistakes and smiled and no one noticed and the world kept turning and later we ate cake on the couch and laughed. There was the version where I didn’t make it at all. There were so many roads.

I took the one that was in front of me. I breathed in between each exit, in between each flicker of taillight, in between the billboards that told me to be a better person and buy a better vacuum and remember my insurance renewal. The sky was pink again, but this time there was a bruise of cloud in the west, and I tried to convince my heart it wasn’t an omen, just water where the light hadn’t got yet. On Onewa, the trees held their roots quiet under the earth; on Constellation, a bus hissed like it had relieved itself; on Oteha, a sign told me to slow down for some reason or other and I did.

When the motorway opened out into the stretch that takes you north of the city, where the hills roll like lazy seals and the sea can’t quite make up its mind to come closer, Cherry hummed a steady rhyme. I patted the dashboard once, twice, three times—one for luck, one for old times, one for Mrs. Healy. The sun came up clean. For a breath, I forgot my mouth was dry.

You’d think, if the world were kind or at least consistent, that would be the end of it, the simple little start of a morning that would file itself under Nice Days. You’d think the yellow cone of light on the road was some sort of blessing, and the radio talking about bees was a sign that sweetness had a plan. In another telling, maybe it was. In the one that happened, I breathed, I drove, I thought of dough and hands and heat and faces I loved, and I felt the very faintest stutter under my foot that could have been nothing and could have been the beginning of everything. I told myself not yet, not yet, not yet.

I drove on. I drove as if the story remembered how to be kind. I drove into a day that had teeth and laughter both, and my hands on the wheel were steady enough to convince me that I belonged to myself, which is all any of us ever get. I drove toward the white tent, and to the place I had made for myself, and if I was also driving toward a crack in the road where the whole thing might catch—well.

Whoever said being an orphan means you don’t have a family never ate cake on this island. We make our families out of sugar and salt and the messy way we show up at each other’s doors. That morning, with the sun lifting and the road obliging and my heart behaving for once, I believed it with a ferocity that warmed my skin. I believed in flour as an instruction manual for resurrection. I believed in the church of kitchens and the prayer of a well-timed timer. I believed in my hands.

And before the day was over, I would need all of that belief, the whole basket of it, stacked high and leaning, wobbling but refusing to fall. For now, the curd sat in its jars. For now, the women at the hospice slept or didn’t. For now, the city shrugged on its jacket. For now—still—there was this bright line of road. I took it, and the gulls, if they watched me from their lamppost councils, squawked like my name was made of sugar and salt and something hard as bone.

Chapter 3

The motorway unspooled like ribbon from a gift you open too slowly, and I kept my hands where they had learned to be, thumbs light, shoulders down, jaw unclenched by force. Dawn did that shy trick where it pretends not to have been planning this all night, and the dark let go of the edges of the hills in stages. Trucks moved like deliberate animals, their taillights blinking a language I had almost learned. I had been a passenger most of my childhood, and then for a long time a walker, and then briefly the kind of girl who thought buses were a kind of moving church because they delivered you somewhere that was not where you started. When I finally learned to drive, it was in a parking lot behind a decommissioned video store, with a volunteer named Mike who smelled like peppermint and had one good joke about parallel parking he refused to ruin by explaining. He taught me to breathe through the merges, to look where I wanted to go instead of where I was afraid I might end up, to trust my hands the way I trusted a whisk. I remembered him now when the lane split at Oteha and I chose the right-hand fork, the one that would take me to a day I had imagined like a cathedral.

Cherry’s little stutter returned once, then thought better of becoming an incident, and flattened out into a hum that steadied me more than the coffee I had only half-finished. The new stretch of motorway rippled under us, and I could feel where the tar had been hot enough to smell new last summer. A sign with cheerful green letters pointed toward Pūhoi, and then Warkworth, and the smaller white sign beneath it whispered Matakana in letters that felt familiar enough to be a promise. The radio told me about bees and then about a finance minister I had no feelings left for, and then—it could have been coincidence—played a song my mother never played, a lullaby disguised as pop, and I let myself sing long low notes on the vowels because sometimes that is the only way to loosen the thread that strangles you.

I stopped once, at a service station that had lived the same life in a hundred towns. I parked under a lamp that blinked like it was bored of its own job and went in to buy water and the kind of barley sugar my grandmother in my head would approve of. The girl at the till had green eyeliner like a deliberate mistake and a badge that said SERA even though she looked like a Sarah who didn’t want to be. She smiled like she had been taught to and then like she meant it when she saw the nervous way I was tapping my fingers against my thighs. There was a rack of pamphlets about wine tours and a poster for a raffle to support a local rugby team, and someone had taped a sign under the EFTPOS machine that said You’re doing great, sweetie. I believed them all for a minute and then pushed the feeling into my pocket with my change. When I came back out, the wind had done something interesting with my hair, and the gull on the roof of the building next door tilted its head at me like we were in on the same long-running joke.

The turn-off to Matakana arrived like a friend pretending to be casual about an important meeting. The road narrowed and then sighed, and the scenery made up its mind to be vineyards and orchards and hills that rolled themselves into the horizon and fell asleep. I drove past a sign for a farmers’ market I’d visited once when my life was more about the price of carrots than the price of flour, and then past a stand selling honey in jars that looked like spare suns, and then a child with a lemon stand that made my whole chest ache with a memory of wanting enough to make things for strangers. The vineyard was only half-hidden; you could see the neat rows of vines from the road like good handwriting, and between them the pale, stubborn gleam of a white tent that had become, for the last months, a symbol that could undo me. Production had overrun the gravel drive with a choreography of vans, cables, and determined people in headsets who all looked like they knew where they were going even when they didn’t.

Security waved me in with a clipboard and a smile that softened at the edges when I said my name. It is one of my secret pleasures to be expected in a place that is not a hospital. A woman with a lanyard that said Poppy in block letters and a pen tucked behind her ear materialized at my window and leaned down like a friendly crane. The smell of wet grass and coffee wove together around her.

“Nia?” she asked, even though my car was labeled and my face was on a sheet somewhere. “Kia ora. You made it. Park over there by the cones, please. Lovely. How are you feeling? Don’t answer that, everyone’s answer is ‘weird’. We’ve got you checked in, temperature today’s perfect for chocolate, and we hid the bees.”

“You can hide bees,” I said, because my mouth had to say something, and there was more of me in that question than I meant there to be.

“We have a guy who whispers to them,” she said, as deadpan as a judge. “You’ll meet him in a minute. Come on. We’ll get you mic’ed up and in out of this breeze.”

In a small, temporary building that had the audacity to pretend it was permanent, I was measured for my day in whispers. A woman with a belt full of tiny miracle machines clipped something to the back of my jeans and ran a wire up under my jumper so that the mic sat just at the hollow of my throat like a necklace that wasn’t allowed to be pretty. I watched my hands while she worked and tried not to swallow because the cord tickled and I didn’t want to be the person who choked on her own hype. In the mirror across the room, a person who looked like me stood in the light and smoothed her eyebrows and tried not to think about how many people would see the shine on her nose. I had dressed without a thought to cameras, except that I had, in a hundred small ways—no stripes too small, no white that would ruin the exposure, the good apron in my bag as if an object could anchor me.

Poppy handed me a laminated schedule that was both a map and a dare. The fonts were too cheerful for what they contained. Signature first, then a break that would be the length of three breaths, then the technical that would separate those of us who had sleep and steel from those of us who had grace, then interviews, then the long slow march to the showstopper that would either crown me or teach me something I would pretend to be grateful for later. She walked me out into the tent and the air lifted a little in my lungs like a relief. Nothing was a surprise and everything was. The long rows of benches were cleaner than any kitchen has a right to be, the equipment gleamed like we were in a catalogue for a life I couldn’t afford, and the sides of the tent bellied in and out with the breeze as if the whole structure was breathing faster than it meant to. Outside, the vines waited like an audience with tans.

My bench was third from the left. Someone had written my name in thick, confident marker on a card taped to the counter, and beneath it someone else had corrected the spelling to include the macron and drawn a tiny smiley face next to the a. It undid me in a quiet, constructive way. I touched the card like it was a little banner, then set my box of ingredients where my hands would reach for them on instinct. The feijoas nestled in the tea towel I had wrapped them in; they smelled like my first summer that didn’t hurt. My piping nozzles checked themselves against the list I had written with a stern voice in my head, and even though I had forgotten the leaf nozzle like a person sleepless about a small thing will always forget the exact small thing she was sleepless about, I felt the jolt of panic and then let it go. I could improvise leaves. I had been improvising leaves since I learned what green tasted like.

Arjun arrived at the bench to my right, wearing an apron that had the tidy, useful stains of someone who treated flour with a level of respect bordering on flirtation. He had once made a puff pastry that looked like it had read the manual first. He moved like a baker in his own kitchen even when the room was full of lenses, and it made me want to stand up straight. To my left, Maia set down a cooler bag with a thump that said she had brought enough butter to issue as rations. Her hair was braided into a plait that had survived a life of weather, and the moko kauae I had seen her get last month was healed now, elegant and sure. It was nice to be stood between a pair of people who understood something about food as a language, and something about stubbornness as a way to be polite to the world.

“Morning, team,” Arjun said, in the muttered way we all said it, like a spell we shouldn't wake up.

“Morena,” Maia said, and squeezed my shoulder once. “You sleep?”

“Like a person who forgot,” I said, and she grinned like the little lie had not fooled her. “You?”

“Like a log on a boat,” she said. “Which is to say, I moved, but I stayed where I was.”

We were shepherded to the front of the tent for a little about-to-happen that would later look like spontaneity. The hosts bounced in with a rush of cold air that made everyone smile because it let us know we were still here, and they did their jokes about us smelling good and being gluttons for punishment. They were kind, and that more than anything loosened my ribs. The judges were the other kind of kind, the kind that doesn’t soften itself down for you because it trusts you enough to take the edges. One had fingers that could tell if a dough was lying; the other had eyes that could see if a cake had decided to be proud. They told us the brief and pretended we didn’t know it already, and I felt the exact level change in the room when everyone found their rhythm inside the rules.

The Signature was what I had been afraid of and also what I had wanted: six lamingtons, elevated but true to their heart, almost identical in size and spirit, with a filling that could tame a stubborn judge. We had two hours, which is the kind of time that seems long until you watch it set itself on fire. I had made a list for this moment, and it was as good as a breath. Eggs, sugar, whip until they remember they were once a little bit sky; flour sifted like mercy; butter folded in like you’re saying sorry and meaning it; bake, cool, don’t cut corners, literally, because crumbs will betray you in the chocolate; curd at body temperature so it will spread like it lives there; coconut toasted because this is a tent and you need every layer of flavour to stand up and be counted when the cameras look at it. I had already decided against jam in a moment that had felt like treason at the time. Instead, I would use the feijoa curd and a line of lime-leaf sugar that had sat in a jar on my counter for a week, learning how to be itself.

They said go and the room changed colour. I beat eggs until they were pale enough to think of themselves as something else, and the sound of the whisk on metal was a rhythm I could set a life to. Pans into the oven, a flick of fingers I didn’t label lucky but was, a glance at the oven thermometer because the numbers on the dial had lied to me before and would do it again if I let them. The tent breathed in and out and we breathed with it, and the camera crew moved around us like they were on a ski slope, all slick glides and unbothered balance. Arjun had his sponge in before I did and was melting chocolate with a seriousness he normally saved for his maths. Maia hummed, and the song was one my bones knew, and because of it I remembered to check the corners of my pan and loosen them with a knife so the sponge would not tear when I tipped it out.

The curd did the thing where it wants to be a sauce, then remembers that you love it, then thickens into the kind of pour that can be trusted. I tasted it the way my grandmother would have, with a finger I pretended not to stick in my mouth, and rolled the sharpness around like a coin. The feijoa had come through. The lime leaf sat like a complicated friend, interesting in the after. I cut squares and tried not to look mournful at the offcuts even though there is a part of me that wants to save everything. I slid them into the blast chiller like a thief returning treasure and stood still for a breath because stillness is an ingredient too.

Chocolate and coconut asked for the kind of attention I’d long been bad at giving. I tempered by eye because my thermometer had a way of scolding me I didn’t appreciate, and I trusted the way the chocolate felt under my spoon when it was ready to behave. I folded in a little cream to soften the snap because lamingtons are not meant to break a tooth, no matter how impressive the shine. The first dip will always tell you your future; mine went in, came out glossy, and caught its snow of coconut with a sigh that made me want to write a poem. That moment doesn’t last, and I knew it, so I set myself to the repeatable actions, building a little assembly line as if I had invented industry. Knife, cut, curd, lid, dip, drip, roll, set, breathe. I kept thinking of Renee standing by the sink in the Avondale kitchen, her cigarette left unlit for ten minutes while she watched me whisk like my life depended on it, saying, “Don’t look at the bowl like it did you wrong. It’s trying its best.”

When the hosts swung by, I found the version of myself that could talk without losing count of breaths. They wanted to know about the feijoa, if I was prepared to fight for it, if I knew half the country loved it and half thought it tasted like potpourri. I smiled like the old woman in me would have when the church ladies said her dress was too red. I said the fruit had raised me, that I was just doing right by it, that the coconut would act like a neighbour who softened the edges of a morning with a loaf delivered wearing a tea towel. They asked if I was worried about the time and I lied so sweetly I almost believed myself.

Across the bench, Arjun was doing a clever thing with pistachios and a cardamom syrup that made the tent smell like a holiday. His lamingtons were square in spirit even if the edges melted into the coconut like they wanted to join another shape, and he had a plan for how to crown them with a little shard of caramel that would look like light caught on the tongue. Maia stayed as true as a compass pointed to her own north. She cooked down wild blackberry jam she had foraged for last summer and carried back like contraband in jars wrapped in old socks. She wiped the edges of each square like a mother wiping a face, and then she did something I loved and would have feared: she rolled the coconut with kawakawa sugar, which let it look like sand that had grown up into a forest.

They laid a shot of the three of us like it was a school picture day where everyone turned up exactly who they were. Nobody said it aloud, but the air held the kind of quiet that meant we all understood what we were doing—trying to speak our names out loud in a room that would always be bigger than us. When the judges came to taste, the tent found another, deeper stillness. The pastry queen cut into mine with a knife that looked like it had been sharpened by the sea, and her eyes did the thing they do when she has decided to be pleased. The other judge did that maddening, wonderful pause like he was writing the sentence in his head so he wouldn’t say it wrong when it came out. They told me my sponge was tender, which in this context is not an insult but a knighthood, and that the feijoa had been handled with respect. One of them tilted their head and said perhaps the chocolate could have been a hair thinner, but then said a thing that folded me open, which was that my lamington tasted like a particular afternoon that could be named if you were brave. I didn’t cry, but the part of me that likes corners more than the middle of rooms considered it.

We stood back and clapped for each other because this was not a war and we had learned what it would mean to make it one. Arjun got praise for balance and a nudge about his corners; Maia got a small lecture about the generosity of her jam and a compliment about courage. The hosts did a joke about coconut in their socks that did not land, and then another about rolling with it that did, and the tent exhaled as one organism. After they had what they wanted from our faces, we were released to the little corner where they had assembled snacks as if to remind us we were animals. I ate a handful of almonds like they had personally offended me and forced my mouth to drink water as if I were apologizing to it with each swallow.

My phone, which I had put face-down in the bag they allowed on the chair by the back of the tent, got to me anyway with its small insistence. In a moment between reality and its filming, I checked it, and there was a message the length of a breath from Coco at the hospice with a picture of Mrs. Healy’s hand making a V that could have been victory or vigilance. Under it was a line that said, Eat, my girl, and remember you can always bake again tomorrow. The way my heart answered could not be called polite. It was a kind of shout that did not make a sound. I ate two more almonds, then a cube of cheese that had sweated itself into honesty, and then I let myself sit for a minute on the step at the back of the tent to look out at the vines and the sky that had already worked through three moods this morning.

For the technical, they took away the scaffolding we’d built around ourselves. The brief was a sheet of paper with instructions designed to look helpful and actually teach you about your beliefs about God. We were told we would be making a mille-feuille, which is French for “a thousand chances to fail” and also for “if you get the lamination right, you will feel a private joy you can’t tell anyone about without sounding smug.” There was going to be pastry cream, which seems easy until it decides to be scrambled eggs; there would be puff pastry from scratch, which would demand everything we had and then ask for a little more; there would be cutting, which is like translation—you could have all the right words and still say something wrong if your knife wandered. We had two hours and forty-five minutes and the kind of cameras that can see through walls.

I looked down at the butter and flour and water that were meant to become layers you could count and then not count. The tent had changed its breathing. People talk about miracles like they are big and obvious, but in kitchens they are small and absolute. Butter at the exact point it can be coerced without broken pride is one. The right amount of water to bring flour together without riling up the gluten is another. The way a bench can hold the cold until your hands learn it is the kind of quiet you only get when you’ve made a friend of a surface. I measured with my eyes and then with the scale because I have learned that my eyes are romantic and the scale is stern. I kept my movements clean and sure, the way Mike had taught me to signal and merge, and I pressed the butter into a rectangle that asked not to be judged too early.

We folded like prayer. Single fold, chill, double fold, turn, chill, the kind of repetition that either bores you or saves you. Arjun muttered numbers under his breath and I watched the way his hands have become less precise and more sure over the past months; Maia sang something under hers and you could hear the paper of it, the way the sound laid itself down in sheets. Between folds, I cooked pastry cream with a whisk that has to be called faithful. Someone’s cream split in the other row and a gentle panic rose like steam and then fell, because the judge leaned in and said two words—cold bowl—and the cream came back to itself like a girl deciding to try again.

The tent did a thing then that I love. It felt like a room where the rules were strict and the people were not cruel. You could feel us wanting each other to succeed because there is nothing interesting about being the best if the people next to you are ruined. I moved my dough to the oven and asked the universe to be reasonable about heat. This particular oven has a personality that can’t be fixed; it thinks it is funny to be bright on the left and shy on the right, and if you do not know how to turn your tray at exactly the right moment, you will cry into a tea towel later. I did my turn, not because of anything I could prove but because my body had learned the timing. When the butter released little breaths, I let myself look pleased for exactly the length of a heartbeat.

There is a point in the technical where no one breathes properly. It’s the cutting. I found the sharpest knife they had provided us, which is to say a knife sharp enough for chopping onions but not for slicing something that demands clean geometry. I heated the blade in hot water and wiped it dry and made a first cut that decided the other cuts. It was almost okay. It was okay enough that a person who loved me would see what I wanted and forgive what I couldn’t make obey me. I stacked cream between pastry with the kind of care reserved for handling a baby or a bomb, and I dusted the top with sugar the way you finish a sentence you hope will land. When the judges came by, I felt the old schoolchild in me want to explain my mistakes before I was asked. I didn’t. I let the sugar speak until it was time for me to say what I meant, which is that this was a technical but also a confession.

Maia’s layers were poems stacked on each other. Arjun’s were a single sonnet that thought it was ten. Mine were tidy enough for a woman who has had to be tidy to live. The comments were the kind that see you from two angles and still hold you in the middle. I got a nod about lamination and a raised eyebrow about a pastry cream that had wanted to go grainy in its hour of pride; I took the criticism like a spoon and stirred it into the stew of myself for later. When we were released for ten minutes that felt like ten seconds, I walked back behind the tent to where the grape leaves stood like a thousand green tongues, and I let myself picture the showstopper without getting too cocky about it.

The sketch in my head for the final bake had gone through several evolutions, many of them crimes. It had wanted to be a croquembouche disguised as a pōhutukawa tree, and then a lamington tower that would inevitably fall like a politician, and then a sensible tart that tasted like home without trying to be clever. In the end, I had found a shape that felt like a handshake with myself. I would make a reef of little cakes and crisp things and gooey things, a low, wide celebration instead of a height contest. There would be feijoa sablé cookies pressed with a floral pattern my body remembered from a plate at a house I left when I was ten. There would be tiny brulée’d tartlets filled with a curd that married lemon and feijoa without making a sound about it. There would be fingers of sponge dipped in a chocolate that didn’t bite, a little ripple of meringue that had behaved itself under a torch, shards of sugar spun thinner than my patience and stuck in place like a vow. It would build outwards like an afternoon on the back steps, the way Mrs. Kline had told me to, and I would not apologize for any of it.

Before they called us back, Poppy came to stand next to me like a person who remembers the exact shape of your bubble. She checked my mic with a practiced flick, then asked if I needed water or a joke or a different life. I asked for the joke, and she told me one about a croissant walking into a bar and being told to leave because the bar was gluten-free, which did not make me laugh until it did. She adjusted the wire at the back of my neck like she was gentling an animal, then let me have one of the small private moments no one tells you are the thread that hold these days together. I put my hand in my pocket to touch the note Mrs. Kline had slipped under my door, and the paper crackled like a dare. There was a smear of butter on it now so faint you’d miss it, and I wondered if everything I loved would eventually carry that mark.

We were called to places and the room narrowed back down to the exact size of my bench. The hosts said something lively that would later be intercut with music that made us sound braver than we were, and the judges looked like they were prepared to be moved and not put up with nonsense. I rolled my shoulders like an athlete in a body that forgot it was one, and I reached for the first thing I needed to bring my idea into the day’s light. Outside the tent, the vines lifted their hands a little in the breeze like they were trying to get a question in. In my head, I could hear Jules saying, Control what you can, and the rest is for ghosts and editors, and I thought, Not today, friends. Today, everything I can hold, I will.

The first hour went the way you pray for without calling it prayer. Butter behaved, flour didn’t sulk, sugar took the hint, and my hands moved in a rhythm that must have been in me from the days before I knew the names for things. I stamped the sablé cookies with the little ceramic press I had borrowed from Lena, the one that made a pattern like the lace on the dress I wore to the fancy fundraiser at the café where we auctioned off croissants to rich people who didn’t know how to eat them. I filled the tart shells with the curd that had learned me and set them on a tray like an army that wanted to be loved. I whipped egg whites with the calm that only comes when you have already cried about meringue enough times that it cannot surprise you, and I leaned my head into the heat of the torch like a cat visiting an altar and kissed the tips of each swirl with gold.

Then the tent did a small trick, the one that turns the second hour into a test of breath. The wind picked up, the side of the marquee belled in, and something in the generator made a sound that could only be described as thoughtful. The lighting flickered like it wanted drama and then remembered the insurance. The hosts did a walk-through of how much time we had left and managed not to make it sound like a threat. The judges toured the room with their eyes and maybe a small part of their hearts. The sound man at my elbow whispered sorry as he adjusted a thing that had migrated across my shoulder blade, and I smiled like I was a person who could carry anything.

I spun sugar because I am occasionally a fool. I heated it to that hard crack stage with the attention you would give a confession, then let it fall in threads off the fork onto the back of a greased ladle, forming little transparencies that would stand where I asked them to like obedient glass. It clumped in one corner when I got cocky and paid the price by burning half a pot that will smell like the end of the world until the end of time. I moved to the stove to rescue the caramel from becoming a weapon, and I bumped elbows with Arjun as he marched past with a tray of choux he had decided at the last minute to add because some people cannot help but be extra. We apologized in a choreography we have practiced for months. I assembled what I could and kept half an eye on the clock that is always a liar and always right.

Cherry flickered in my mind then, in the exact moment a patch of sugar cooled too much to bend to my will. It was the memory of the stutter, the suggestion of the little cough that had made me say not yet, not yet. I placed the sugar aside and reminded that part of my brain that there is no version of this day where going back to the car will fix anything except the way I talk to myself. The hosts swung by again with a comment about how pretty the sugar looked like winter on a glasshouse, and I told them I didn’t believe in winter and they pretended to be scandalized and I laughed, which is to say I performed a small exorcism on the panic.

When the third hour hit, it didn’t ask for permission. Chocolate had to be melted again because it had gone off to sulk in a corner; coconut, which had been waiting politely, suddenly wanted attention like a toddler at a funeral; the curd asked to be trusted one more time and coasted over the line like a girl crowd-surfing. I placed the last tartlet and then moved three things half a centimetre like that would save us all. Behind me, Maia put her hand on her hip and closed her eyes for a second as if hearing an answer to a question she had not asked aloud. To my right, Arjun swore in a language that sounded like home to him, then grinned because sometimes it is a relief to hear yourself swear in your own words.

We did the final tidy the way you tidy the room where you were kissed for the first time—it doesn’t matter, but also it matters. The call came with that fake-chipper tone to put down our tools, and I did, even the part of me that thought I could stick one more little shard of sugar in and not have it collapse did. I stepped back from the bench and looked at the thing I had made, and it looked back at me with the face of every kitchen I have ever stood in. It was imperfect and glorious and had my fingerprints all over it, as every true thing does. When they asked me what it was, I said the sentence I had been afraid of saying because of what it gives away. I said, “It’s a backyard afternoon with a mother I don’t remember and a woman who taught me to say please to butter, and it’s mine, and it wants you to sit down and stay.”

They took their time. The cameras leaned in from their leashes. The judge cut one of the tartlets and let the curd sigh onto the plate, and the other judge broke a sablé between his fingers and listened to the sound like it could tell him my name. The hosts did their job and got out of the way in a way that deserves medals. I let the breath out of my body and did not take another one until they nodded at something I could not yet read as blessing or lesson.

And then the thing happened that I had been waiting for without admitting it. A runner from Production appeared at the side of the tent as if conjured from a prayer, her face that particular calm that only ever means one of two things. She crossed to me with that delicate, unflappable walk you learn from carrying plates of hot food through rooms full of people looking at you. She touched two fingers to the place on my arm where skin is thinnest and spoke quietly enough that the microphones had to strain. “Nia,” she said, gentle but with the weight of her being paid to tell the truth. “Before we do the judging. It’s Mrs. Healy. They rang through. She asked that if we could find you, we would. She says she’s fine and she’s not fine, and she says to tell you to say what you meant to say anyway.”

The tent, which had been a single sound all day, seemed to stand back to let me hear that sentence. There is a way that news moves through a body; it doesn’t ask for your heart first. It goes straight for your knees and your taste and the little muscles in your face that keep you upright when the tide pulls. I nodded and then I shook my head and then I remembered how to hold my neck. “Is there—” I started, and the runner, whose badge said TARA in looping letters, shook her head once like a person who had been told to be careful with the spirit she was handling.

“She’s being looked after,” Tara said, and when she said looked after it held a universe. “She wanted me to say, Make sure they smell the lemon. She was very clear on that. Do you want to call? Not now, but—she wanted you to know before, not after.”

If I had been alone, I would have become one of those people who kneel on kitchen floors. There is a tile back in Avondale that knows the shape of my knees. In the tent, with a camera pretending not to watch and a judge pretending not to care that they were watching, I did the thing I have learned to do. I built a little room inside myself and put the news in it with water and a blanket and said, I will be back in a minute, my love. I looked at the showstopper like it could tilt the world back into order, and then I looked at Tara and said, “Tell them I’m ready,” and meant it, which surprised me enough that I smiled.

The judging went on, because judging always goes on, because this is the deal we make with narrative. They ate our afternoons and our stubbornness and our faith in butter. They spoke in sentences that tried to hold the shape of fairness. They looked at us like we were trying to add something to the vocabulary of sugar and they were prepared to hear us out. When they got to me and asked what I called it, I didn’t repeat the speech I had practiced because I am not a person who was built to say anything twice the same way. I said, “It’s called Back Steps,” and when they asked me why I told them about Mrs. Kline’s note, about Renee’s hands, about a girl who stood at the edge of a room and counted the plates in case there weren’t enough, and about the first time I learned that you can feed a person and make them less alone for ten minutes. I said it like I was allowed to be a person who speaks in tents with lights on her face.

They nodded, and the pastry queen did that thing where she presses her lips together to keep something from escaping that might be mistaken for too much feeling. The other judge looked down at his notes and then up like he had remembered there was a person attached to the food. They said the curd was daring and the sablé carried the pattern like a secret, and they teased me about spinning sugar without a safety net like I believed in angels. They gave me one tiny fix I would make every time for the rest of my life—the chocolate on the sponge could have been thinner still, like the line between being proud and being arrogant—and then they handed me back my own afternoon, slightly rearranged but intact.

After, when they sent us to be filmed pretending we were not about to be told our fates, I found a corner of the vineyard that had been left alone by humans for the morning. It was a little place behind a low wall where weeds had elected a council and a spider had written a letter to someone I will never meet. I pressed my phone between my hands until it warmed like a living thing and called the number for the hospice that I had learned without meaning to, the way you know the rhythm of your name spoken by someone who loves you.

Coco answered because Coco always answers. The sound of the fluorescent lights came through like a gentle reprimand. She said my name like she was smoothing a tablecloth. She told me two things at once—you did good, and she is thinking of you—and then filled in all the little places between them with details so that I wouldn’t have to imagine the wrong ones. Mrs. Healy had had a dip. The kind that makes the nurses speak softly and the day move sideways. She had refused being fussed over and then accepted a glass of water like a queen. She was letting the pills pull her into a place where she might see someone who has been waiting for her. She had, Coco said, asked me to listen very carefully when I heard whatever I was about to hear.

“I’ll come tonight,” I said, already counting the exits home in my head.

“Come if you can,” Coco said, always practical. “Drive like you have sense. Eat something. She hates it when you don’t eat.”

“I ate almonds,” I said, which is not food, and Coco made the noise she makes when she doesn’t agree but will let you make your own mistakes until you are ready to confess and be fed.

Back in the tent, the air had found a new shape again. Someone had righted a light that had wanted to tilt into metaphor. The hosts were practising a line that would carry the right weight without sinking the room. Arjun flicked a crumb off the corner of his shirt with the kind of concentration normally reserved for tying knots, and Maia looked out at the vines and then back at her hands like she had just remembered where her power lives. We stood in the little semi-circle they had told us to stand in like a day care for grown-ups with oven burns, and we did the thing we had promised ourselves we would do a hundred times: we breathed and we did not let our faces give away every room inside of us.

They told us, because they must, who had stood a little taller today. They used the language that is decorous and decided by committees, and inside of it there were words that were for us alone. When they said my name in the way that meant I had done what I came to do, the world tilted but did not fall. I did not drop my face into my hands because I had been taught to be polite in public, but it would be a lie to say I did not picture doing it. They put a hand on my shoulder and did not hold on too hard. Arjun and Maia hugged me in a sandwich that smelled like sugar and clean steel, and I hugged them back in the exact way that meant I would buy their first books and send them messages when their babies were born, whether those babies were bread or breathing.

After, when the images had been gathered and the people with the clipboards said we could be human beings again, I found a bench outside the tent where the sun had warmed a patch just for me. I sat down and put my head in my hands and then lifted it right back up because I could hear Renee in my bones telling me to mind my hair if I wanted to look like myself on camera later. I drank water until my ribs felt like they had been asked to stop being instruments and become a house. My phone buzzed again, and there was a message from Lena that was all caps and exclamation points and a picture of a tray of meringues that had been burned by a love that was too hot and then rescued anyway. There was one from Kahu that said simply, You did it? and another that said, I told the gulls, which made me laugh on a sound that startled a bee.

The day was not over, not by a long stretch. There would be interviews where I would tell the story like I had known all along what I was doing, and there would be shots of me walking down a row of vines that would make me look like a person who thinks in neat rows. There would be the packing away of the little kitchen I had built in an hour and a half, and the moment where everyone goes quiet for five seconds for a sound thing, and the way the tent looks when it is only a big, silly piece of fabric and not the inside of a dream. There would be the drive back through the afternoon, when the traffic would forget it remembered me this morning, and the stop at the dairy where the same man would sell me milk and I would tell him the cricket score he already knew. There would be the hospice in the blue hour, and the smell of lemon hand gel and hope, and the seat by the bed where I would put my elbows and fold my hands and say what I had meant to say to Mrs. Healy even if she was watching from a little ways away.

I stood because standing seemed like a new thing to try. I walked because it would mean I might eventually get to the door. I put my hand on the tent pole at the edge of the world they had built and felt the whole structure shiver the way it does when a gust runs through, and I remembered the first time the gulls learned my name. They are not sentimental birds, gulls. They will take what you hold if you leave it on a table. They screamed my name like it was something to do to fill the morning. Today, they could have it. I had enough names for myself to share.

Chapter 5

In the weeks between the tent and the television, the secret sat in my pocket like a hot stone I didn’t know whether to hold onto or put down. I carried it past the café counter where Lena double-checked her cinnamon to make a point, past the noticeboard at the dairy where someone had thumbtacked a flyer for a missing budgie named Shrek, past the hospice where the windows practiced being kind to everyone who looked through them. Production took me to a room with too much white and told me how to be myself, on message. Poppy put a fresh lanyard around my neck like it was a medal and showed me where to stand so the light forgave me. I smiled next to a pyramid of lemons that had been wiped to within an inch of their dignity and lifted a whisk with an expression that belonged on a saint who’d been told the carving would last longer if she stopped moving. They needed photos of me that didn’t look like anyone who had taken off their shoes in the kitchen at midnight to talk to a jar of curd, so I tried to imagine I was the kind of woman who could predict the weather by the sound the oven made when it settled.

Mrs. Healy began to drift like a boat untethered from a wharf she’d been born beside and had always meant to leave. I went in the mornings with scones too soft inside and just proud enough on the outside to be forgiven, and in the afternoons with citrus tarts that looked like the sun had taken its hat off and stayed. Some days she woke sharp and clear and told me stories about a boy who had loved her once and brought her peaches so ripe they made the kitchen blush, about a garden where beans had climbed up into the roof and taught her that you can coax anything if you plant it with your whole chest. Other days, she floated somewhere gentle and let my voice fill the room like a radio left on low in another flat. Coco kept lavender at her wrists because she understood what it was to trick the air into thinking everything was less hard than it was, and she showed me how to tuck a blanket in at the corners like you were promising something you could keep. When pain came, it dropped its anchor and didn’t pretend otherwise. Mrs. Healy would watch it like it was an uninvited guest at a party, then wave it into the kitchen and tell it there was tea, and if it wanted to stay it would have to listen to three jokes first.

The night I drove across town fast for no reason I could name, the sky was that thin indigo that reminds you how big it gets when you’re not looking. Cherry hummed like a woman pretending to hum who is really pleading. The hospice doors opened with the hush of something practiced, and the nurse at the desk looked up and knew my name like she was expecting me, which, as it turned out, she was. The room was dim in the way of rooms that have decided to be kind by being quiet, and the lemon on the hand gel walked the line between hospital and heaven. Mrs. Healy’s breath did the soft, stubborn work it had learned, and her hair was a crown of wild white spun sugar against the pillow. I sat where I always sat and told her everything about the tent except the part I wasn’t allowed to say, and that made her smile, because the woman loved a rule that bent a little for the right person. When she woke enough to press my fingers with hers, she said, Don’t get thin, remember to salt your butter, and when they cut you open with kindness, say thank you and then eat. I told her there was a tart cooling on my counter with her name on it. She said, Let it be for the living, then closed her eyes like a door that knows exactly where it is on its hinges.

Grief has its own tight little chores. I buttered toast I didn’t want and ate it because Coco’s face told me I would be watched if I didn’t. I went out to the car and cried in the exact shape of the steering wheel because sometimes that is the only place you can hold the sob and not spill it on someone else’s shoes. Kahu turned up on the steps after sunup with two coffees and a bag of mandarins and a way of leaning his shoulder against mine that reminded my bones they were not hollow. We made lists even then—death requires them as much as television does—and put things on them we could tick off with a hand that shook less when it had something to do. The hospice women took my cake and turned it into a table that looked like a quilt. The knitting ladies put their spiky love into a blanket with a mistake in the corner on purpose so nothing would be asked to be perfect. Someone from the Tuesday group sang a song I didn’t know I knew the words to, and when we carried Mrs. Healy out on a morning that had decided to be ordinary despite everything, the gulls went quiet at the window as if even they had a gentle bone.

It is strange, to lift a win that won’t be public for weeks alongside a loss that is loud right now. I walked through days with my tongue caught between my teeth to keep from spilling, and every so often the secret would warm my pocket and threaten my mouth. Lena kept me on the machine and off the internet. People came into the café and said things like, Are you that girl, and I’d prefer an oat flat white if you have it, and my cat has developed a taste for brioche, and anyway, we’re all proud of you, hun, and I took the coins and gave the change and tried to imagine every mouth had sugar in it. A man with paint under his nails who fixed fences for a living told me he’d never watch a baking show on purpose, then asked if lamingtons had rules, and when I said they did, he nodded like it was good to know there were laws somewhere. I went to Tasi’s with lamingtons and a brioche and he told me that Cherry was singing like a choir that had been paid in pies. He wiped his hands on a rag, said the word sister the way a man says it when he means more than blood, and offered to paint the tyres bench if I ever needed somewhere to sit people down and feed them for money.

On the day the episode would finally air, Auckland put on a sky as thin as muslin that let the light through anyway. We put a sign on the community centre door that said Bring a plate and a story, and the people showed up with both like they had been told there were only enough chairs for those who remembered who they were. Kahu borrowed the hospice projector because the hospice is generous in both directions, and wrangled an extension cord that had opinions about being tripped over. Tasi arrived with a tray of panipopo that made the air reconsider itself and a look like he had done something smug he wasn’t going to brag about. Mrs. Kline came down the stairs with Beethoven in a little harness she had knit out of unlikely yarn and an expression that said she did not plan on asking permission to be present. Arjun texted a picture of three bowls he’d set out on his kitchen table labelled salt, sugar, tears, and Jules called from Christchurch and propped their phone against a jar of pickles so I could watch the dance the light made across their wall when they laughed.

The room smelled like garlic bread, cheap paper plates, and a dozen secrets lightly salted. A boy I remembered from a house I left when I was eight turned up taller and softer and said, Do you remember the dog we weren’t supposed to have, and I said, I remember the dog we had anyway. Lena organized people the way she organizes sugar on a bench, which is to say with efficiency and an eye for where sweetness is needed most. I put the Back Steps platter on a table near the wall with the peeling paint like a set piece for a life I recognized. The sablé had kept their pattern; the little tartlets sat like good children pretending not to be clever, and the meringue had not wept in the car, which felt like a personal miracle. We turned the volume up too loud at first because we were afraid of missing anything, then turned it down because the sound of ourselves was a better soundtrack than anything that had been edited for us.

Watching yourself is an out-of-body experience if the body you leave behind is holding a plate of sausage rolls. I saw my hand before I saw my face, saw the way flour clung to the heel of my palm and the way I set a bowl down like it could startle. The tent looked cleaner and sillier than it had felt, and my bench looked like a place I had grown up by accident and only realized when I had to say goodbye. The hosts made jokes we had laughed at already and then again because they had been given a nicer home. The judges said words I knew they had said and they still felt like a hand on my shoulder when I needed it. The lamingtons didn’t crumble under the chocolate this time, on screen. The mille-feuille cut clean as a sentence with no apologies. My mouth on camera said, It’s called Back Steps, and I heard the ripple in the room behind me before the show heard it, and it sounded like a little neighbourhood saying we see you.

When the moment came, they made an entire country hold its breath for exactly the length of time that makes you hate everyone with a clipboard and then forgive them all at once. They said my name. They said it without mangling it, with the a the way it is written, and someone had remembered the macron, and I felt that thing again that is not quite being born and not quite being undressed. The room went up like a pan deglazed with wine. The sound was a cheer and a laugh and a sob and the brittle clatter of cutlery hitting plates and not breaking. I was hugged from six directions by people who all thought they were the only one who knew to hold me under the ribs where it counts, and Beethoven screamed at the ceiling because that is how he expresses joy at scale.
