Lena cried like a kettle and pretended she’d got something in her eye; Kahu stood on a chair and nearly fell off and then stood on it again because he liked being taller than a moment for once; Mrs. Kline whacked me on the arm with a bonne chance nobody asked her to translate, and Tasi slipped three savoury pies into my bag with a wink because he is a man who plans your hunger before you feel it.

My phone forgot how to be silent. Messages arrived like cicadas. Some were friends who had been holding their breath in other rooms. Some were strangers who wanted to tell me about the first time their grandmother had let them stir the batter and how they had never felt worthy since, and would I send them the recipe for feeling needed. One was from a woman named Beth who said she had sat in a kitchen with a woman named Renee who used to talk about a girl who whisked like she was trying to beat life into something that had forgotten itself, and was that possibly me. It was as if a match had been struck and left burning in my chest. Another was a number I didn’t recognize that said simply, You made it taste like afternoons. The hospice sent me a picture of the TV in the staff room and three nurses pretending not to cry. The café’s page tagged me in a post that said, Our girl, and a photo of a lamington that had tried its best and mostly succeeded.

I took my plate of tartlets out onto the back steps because I had promised Mrs. Kline and because I needed air that had not been breathed by a hundred beloveds. The concrete held the heat like a lap. The alley smelled like jasmine and the world’s oldest mop. A cat that was not Beethoven drifted past with the disposition of a poet trying to remember a rhyme for hunger. Down on the street, a gull stood on the bonnet of a stranger’s car and contemplated its life with an admirable seriousness, then screamed two notes that somehow added up to my name. Jules’ face wobbled on my phone in that way of video calls and then stilled, their smile big enough to tilt the moon. They didn’t say Well? because friends who have the right kind of manners don’t ruin a good question, but their eyes did the asking for them. I held up the last tart and bit into it and held the other half to the screen like a sacrament, and we both laughed for a while before we remembered what crying’s for.

By the end of the night, the tables looked like a dozen small festivals had been held on them and everyone had gone home full. I wiped them down with water that turned flour to thick little ghosts under my cloth and put the chairs back where they would pretend to live until next time. People came and went in waves and left me with words I kept picking up later to see how they felt in the hand. A woman I didn’t recognize hugged me and said, You’ve changed nothing and everything, which I plan to embroider on the nearest tea towel. When almost everyone had left, Mrs. Kline tottered over with something wrapped in waxed paper and a look like she had been saving this too long and might break if she didn’t pass it on. Inside was a photograph bleached at the edges and softened by too many summers, and in it, a younger me stood on a bench in a kitchen I had not visited in years, holding a wooden spoon like it was a microphone, while a woman with a scar at her eyebrow and hands like weather laughed behind me. On the back, in a blunt pencil, someone had written NIA + RENEE’S SCONES—FIRST TRY, and the year that made my stomach make a sound of its own.

“How—” I tried, but Mrs. Kline was already nodding her head like a small, smug metronome.

“Community centre clear-out, long time ago,” she said. “No one claimed the box. I don’t like things that get lost. You can’t keep every stray, but some of them will just live under the bed if you let them.”

I took the picture like it would jump. “Do you know if—”

“If she’s alive?” Mrs. Kline’s eyes were as kind as they have ever been and sharp as I have ever known them. “I don’t know. I know somebody who keeps track of people who keep track of people. I also know the way you said her name.”

The next morning, the air tasted like it had rained without the sky admitting it. I woke to seventeen requests to make a cake that looked like a lighthouse and one to make biscuits shaped like a cat named Tango, and a very serious email from a morning show asking if I could be cheery at a time of day when I normally look like a cautionary tale. I said yes to what I could and no to the things that made my stomach clench, and I put the kettle on and sent a message to a market manager in Matakana asking about stall fees and whether you could share a power point without starting a family feud. Kahu came out of his room with his hair doing that thing where it looks like a hero fresh from a wind tunnel and waved a printout that said Business Plan Template as if it were a seashell he’d found and wanted to teach to sing. He insisted his thesis brain could carry a bakery as easily as it could carry the price of water under colonialism, and I let him because it made him happy to have a new river to argue with.

I went for a walk down to the shops because I wanted the world to confirm it had noticed nothing and also everything. A girl on a scooter grinned at me and said, Nice cakes, and didn’t stop. The dairy man told me the cricket score before I asked and slid an extra barley sugar into my hand like I was a child who had managed not to cry at the hairdresser. Mr. Singh’s wife told me in a whisper that she had started putting coconut on everything and that her husband now thought he was allergic to success. The florist two doors down had copied out a quote about living deliberately and hung it upside down in the window because the tape had ideas. The city kept being itself, which is to say, it carried me whether I knew it or not.

At home, I cleared the table with the reverence of someone laying out tools. The photograph went in the centre like a small altar. I wrote two lists—one called Back Steps and one called People Who Knew Renee—and I let the pencil choose how big the letters would be. On the Back Steps list, I wrote things like find a cheap oven that will not explode, learn how to say no to people who bring you avocados and expect cake, ask Tasi about a kettle big enough to bathe a baby in, file forms even if they feel like they are asking for pieces of you you need. On the other, I wrote names that tasted old on my tongue, a neighbour who had known everyone and had a memory like a recipe box, a social worker with soft shoes who had once cried in a hallway and thought no one had seen, a woman at the community centre who had kept her hair in a tight bun that could have been a weapon if you were foolish, and a boy who had called himself an only child even when he wasn’t.

And then—because when life gives you a day you start a thing that will fail without witness—I baked. Not for anyone who would pay me or write about me or hand me a ribbon, but for the back steps I could see from my kitchen window, the concrete sun-warmed and unglamorous and waiting. I made the scones from the old recipe whose card I had copied with the indecent care of a thief. I cut in the butter until the flour looked like it had been snowed on without malice, and I added the milk in the careful measure that sits somewhere between parsimony and love, and I patted the dough out with an open hand, which is really the only way to make it behave. I stamped circles with a glass that had once held cheap beer at a party I still haven’t forgiven, brushed the tops with cream like a blessing, and baked them until they had the colour of good shoes. I took them outside with a jar of jam I had been saving and a tin of condensed milk nobody admits to but everyone uses when they have something to say in sugar.

I sat on the step and split a scone and the steam made a point, and I put jam and milk on it and ate with my eyes closed because there are times when that is the only way to register your life. The alley hummed. The sun slid itself up over the roofline with the laziness of a cat at noon. A gull landed on the fencepost and looked at me like a judge. I held out the last bite because I am not above bribing the wild, and it took it and made a sound that would have been a laugh in any other animal. My phone buzzed in my pocket with a new message from an unknown number that began, I think I know where she is, and the blood rushed to the places inside me that usually only open for hot water and weather. I licked the jam off my thumb and looked at the photograph again and believed the thing hard enough that sometimes you get what you want. I believed that the steps you take because you promised someone you'd do a thing you said out loud are the kinds that make a small path appear where it wasn’t before, and if you’re lucky, and if you’re stubborn, and if the gulls have learned your name, the path doesn’t vanish when you stop looking.

In the days that followed, I learned to turn down some offers with a grace I know I didn’t grow myself. A magazine wanted me to stand in a dress that would not forgive me if I ate lunch and hold a whisk like a baton; I said no with thanks and offered them a recipe that came with a paragraph about a woman with a scar in her eyebrow and a laugh that could teach a spoon its job. A radio show asked me to come on and talk about resilience, which I almost did until I remembered I am not a story you can bottle for commuting. The morning television took me anyway, a woman painted until I recognized myself only in the corners, and Poppy stood where I could see her and tipped her head when I started to talk too fast. I told the country to salt their butter and to stop being ashamed of their sweet tooth and to meet their neighbours because there is no recipe that doesn’t start with that. Back at the café, Lena put me on dishes and told the staff that fame had not softened me, and I told her to tell them I had hidden my spine in the cutlery drawer.

Evenings found me in front of cupboards with a phone tucked under my chin, calling numbers that had been given to me by numbers who remembered other numbers. People who keep track of people had been kinder to me than I deserved for most of my life; sometimes they were busy and sometimes they were weary, and mostly, they had stories that made us both sit down. A woman at a shelter told me Renee had taught a girl she wasn’t related to how to tell the difference between the smell of soap and the smell of lies, and we were quiet for a bit because sometimes all you can do when given a detail like that is let it change the tilt of the room. An old landlord told me he’d liked the way she always lined up her shoes by the door, ready to run if someone needed running after. A boy who had become a man with tattoos like declarations told me she had let him sleep on her couch and had made him pancakes she’d called flapjacks with a voice that made him fill the sink to wash up like he could save something.

The lead from the message that had started with I think I know where she is pulled like a kite string. A nurse in Tauranga had heard a story about a woman who’d moved down the coast to help a cousin and had stayed to look after a woman she had found crying on a bus. A man in a bar in Ōhope said his aunt had bought scones from someone who made them so right you remembered your dead when you ate them, and he was not a man who had meant to remember anyone that day. A library volunteer in Whakatāne sent me a photograph of a noticeboard where a flyer with a blunt pencil had advertised a Saturday baking class, Gold coin donation, No fuss, Don’t be rude about my oven. The email came with a second photo of a woman’s hands rolling a dough you could almost smell. She had a scar at her eyebrow. Her hair had gone silver like a mercy. The kind of hope that makes the ribs sore set up camp and started boiling water for tea.

I asked Kahu if he wanted a road trip and he said he had an academic meeting and then laughed like that was a joke. We packed the car with bananas, a bag of scones that Lena had insisted on making though she swore she would never be sentimental in pastry again, two thermoses, a blanket that had seen better beaches, and the photograph in a plastic sleeve like it was a passport. Tasi checked Cherry’s tyres and put his hand on the bonnet and told her to behave and then told me to call if she didn’t and not to be proud about it. Mrs. Kline gave me a list of things to say to strangers if they looked at me like a feral child and reminded me that people in other cities are also people, which I accused her of knowing firsthand and she admitted quietly. Jules called to say, If it’s not her, it is someone else someone will need you to bake for, and the sentence was a map.

We took the road east like we meant it. The city loosened its grip and the land remembered water, and the radio did that thing where it forgets your mood and then gets it right by accident. The sky decided to be neither spectacular nor sulking, the exact kind you can drive under without imagining anyone is watching you from behind it. On the Paeroa stretch, billboards told us who to vote for and where to buy tyres and how to get rid of a mould problem with vinegar and something that absolutely wasn’t bleach, promise. At the big L&P bottle, we got out and took a picture we pretended not to take because we are not tourists even when we are, and Kahu said the thing about lemon and Paeroa and secret recipes in a voice that made even the sign look like it was tired of being asked. The gulls, somehow, had come east ahead of us and were waiting on a roof in the main street like a meeting had been called.

We found the community hall with the noticeboard without having to ask. The flyers on it were sun-faded except for the one with the blunt pencil—a Saturday baking class with a date that suggested she had been here long enough for people to expect her on Saturdays. Inside, the hall smelled like varnish and shoes and something baked last week. A whiteboard announced a meeting of the midweek walkers and a raffle for a hamper that contained two kinds of chutney and a bottle of wine with a label that had birds on it. There were stacks of chairs that had known a hundred meetings where nothing happened and two where everything did. I stood in the doorway as if I could step into my own photograph. The room did not turn into a cathedral. It was just a room. You want that for your lives, if you are lucky: for things to be exactly themselves when you arrive in them.

A woman came in from the kitchen with flour at the hinge of her thumb and a face I had learned in a place that smelled like rain and cheap deodorant. She stopped moving, briefly, in the way that points are made. The scar at her eyebrow lifted as if it wanted to be counted among the present. She said my name like it had never been mispronounced by a teacher and I hadn’t left it behind anywhere, and I said hers like it couldn’t have belonged to anyone else ever. We looked at each other with the caution you give something fragile that has forgotten it is also made of bone. Then she crossed the room with a dishtowel in one hand and a spoon in the other because no one who loves as their first language arrives empty, and she put her hand against my cheek the way she had put it there in a different kitchen in a different suburb on a day when the power had gone out and the gas oven had been a miracle.

“I taught you to cut butter with two knives,” she said, and the knife in her voice had softened in the places where knives need to do that.

“And you told me not to throw away a batch,” I said. “Even the sinners.”

“We are all of us saints sometimes,” she said. “Did you bring your own apron?”

I had. It was in the bag because I am a woman who prepares for polite ambushes. We went into the kitchen because it is the room where we know what to say. Kahu stood in the doorway like a cousin who understands this is not his scene and also entirely is, and he found a kettle and put it on because tea is an act of love too short to be misinterpreted. Renee took out one bowl, and then another, and put them down with a rhythm I recognized from rooms where I’d had to count chairs and fights and silences. She handed me a bag of flour and said, Show me, and I showed her, and we did not speak for the length of time it takes to rub in butter with your fingertips until it disappears and reappears as weather.

Later, we would say all the things that hurry to the edge of the mouth in reunions and decide which ones to let jump. We would lay out the years like towels on a fence and look at the stains and decide which ones mattered and which ones were simply proof we had lived. She would tell me where she had gone when she left the house in Avondale and why. I would tell her about Mrs. Healy and the tent and the gulls and the feeling of holding the wheel and telling the car not yet. She would tell me about the girls and the boys and the not-quite-grown she had taught to boil water without burning it and to make rice without breaking into pieces when it stuck. I would tell her about Back Steps and how a photograph you handed in a kitchen could become a place on a map you’d been making with your whole body.

For now, we made scones because there are times when language has to be eaten before it can be understood. The oven in the hall was older than any of us and had the temperament of an auntie who would lend you money and call you at six in the morning to ask about it in a voice that actually wanted to know if you were warm enough. We put the tray in and crouched in front of the glass like hopeful children watching a trick, and when the tops browned and rose and leaned into each other like neighbours, we smiled with half our faces, the half that remembered each other from another life. We took them out and split one open and put butter on it and watched it melt, and then we put our tongues on the past and found it could be sweet without being untrue. We sat on the back steps of that hall, the same concrete as every hall in every town, and ate what we had made and looked at the road as if it had been waiting for us to sit down so it could continue.

Outside, a child yelled something that didn’t need translating. The gulls, late to the party for once, arrived in a ragged little cloud and argued about nothing on the roof. The sun found a way through the clouds like it always had a plan to arrive and was only being dramatic. It would be a long drive home, and then a longer run of days with forms and flour and the terrible joy of telling people where to stand and where to find the bathroom. There would be a market with a stall that would be mine and not mine because nothing we make is ever only ours. There would be a sign that said Back Steps in letters I would probably paint wrong the first time and then leave like that because perfection is boring. There would be mornings when the stove ran hot and evenings when the curd lined up in jars like good soldiers and nights when the gulls forgot my name and I learned not to mind because I had enough other names to answer to.

“Are you happy?” Renee asked, not as an accusation but as a line you could tie a boat to.

“Sometimes,” I said. “More often when there’s butter.”

“Smart girl,” she said. “Bring your people here on Saturdays if you like. We can teach a lot of ladies with sharp elbows how not to cut scones like murderers.”

We laughed because it was the right noise. We ate another scone because life is short and then long and then complicated, and you need to have something in your hands for all of it. The day didn’t clap or bow or take our picture. It did the better thing. It stayed.

Chapter 7

The week after we found each other in a hall that smelled like varnish and old biscuits, the world began to behave as if it had been watching us decide. Papers appeared that wanted my full name in block letters and my grandmother’s maiden name like a test I hadn’t studied for. The market manager in Matakana sent a cheery email with a PDF attached that looked friendly until it mentioned food safety, access to potable water, and whether I owned a gazebo that wouldn’t murder a child if the wind got ambitious. Kahu put his thesis into a drawer like a lover he’d promised to call and pulled out a dry-erase marker with the lust of a man who’d been waiting his whole life to draw a Gantt chart. He wrote Back Steps across the top of the whiteboard on our fridge in letters that got bolder with each loop, then stood back with his arms crossed like a small, pleased god.

“It’s not a bakery,” he said, as if correcting a child. “It’s a project. A kaupapa. A moving kitchen. A way to make people less annoyed at mornings.”

“It’s also a table,” I said. “And my job is to make sure there’s enough to put on it.”

He nodded with the seriousness of a man who did not plan to let gravity get in the way of his enthusiasm. He assigned himself the task of sign procurement and logo design with a flourish, then reached for his phone to text three friends who all had opinions about fonts. We learned that there are arguments you cannot avoid if you love anything: what to call the shade of green that says leaf and not toothpaste, whether a macron should sit above a letter if you cannot guarantee the printer will respect it, how many gulls you can draw before it becomes a children’s book. The sign arrived a week later, painted by someone in Grey Lynn who’d done bands and barbershops and one wedding he refused to be held responsible for. BACK STEPS, it said, in a hand that looked like it would swear for you if necessary. The S leaned into the P as if sharing a secret.

Renee travelled up on a Friday with a sack of lemons from a tree that had decided to be generous and a list of people she thought we should ask for help. She wrote their names on an envelope with her thumb pressed against the paper like she could steady the future through friction. She had a way of leaning on the bench with her hip that made every kitchen she entered look like it had been waiting; when the kettle boiled, she tilted her head to listen as if it were about to sing something particular for her. We worked through the food safety check with the sort of laughing that makes inspectors less inclined to reject you. The man from the council was gentle and alarmingly thorough. He wanted to know if my thermometers were calibrated, whether I had a handwashing setup that would function even if the power cut without warning, whether my wiping cloths were of a colour that wouldn’t hide blood if I did something stupid to myself. He watched me wash my hands as if he had been asked to write a sonnet about it. By the time he left, he had a bag of lemon slices and the knowledge that we would not poison anyone on purpose.

The first Saturday was a rehearsal for a life. We loaded Cherry with tables, an Esky full of curd and cream and butter that had all the excitement of a hen party on a ferry, a stack of brown paper bags we’d stamped with the new logo until the kitchen smelled like ink, and three dozen scones Renee called insurance. The sign fit in the backseat like a passenger, and I buckled it in because I didn’t trust physics. At the market, the air had the feel of a poem that had been rewritten until it could be read out loud without making its owner blush. Stalls lined up and pretended to be orderly. Someone sold candles with names like Quiet Field and Monday Morning; someone else had knitted child-sized hats with ears that would ruin them for life in the best way; a beekeeper stood behind a run of jars like he was offering parts of the sun for a reasonable price and told everyone who paused that his girls were in a good mood today. The woman at the end wore a T-shirt that said BREAD IS MY LOVE LANGUAGE and thick socks and a smile that made me want to hand her all my secrets.

We set up the gazebo with the clumsiness of people who have never triangulated anything. The wind came across the vines with the intention of reminding us it had been here first. A man appeared as if conjured, tightened a knob Kahu had been wooing for fifteen minutes, drove a peg into a patch of ground that had ideas about staying inviolate, and faded back into the general population with a nod. I made a chalkboard menu in handwriting that would have made my year ten teacher sigh. Back Steps: feijoa lemon tartlets, scones with jam and condensed milk, hyped-up lamingtons, shortbread like you forgot to behave, coffee from Lena’s machine if the power fairy stays with us. Renee added and a slice of something if we don’t eat it first in a neat slope to the corner. We put the plate of samples at the front and the spoon in the jar of curd within my arm’s reach as if I were offering communion. The gulls did a low reconnaissance pass, then decided we were either not generous or not interesting and went to harass a child who had unwrapped a muesli bar with the assurance of the unafraid.

People came. That first hour tasted like a childhood birthday party where everyone actually turns up. The early risers with their canvas bags and opinions on tomatoes stopped and nodded as if we had met somewhere else in a life with better lighting. The kids came for the lamingtons and stayed to argue about what feijoa tastes like to people who think they hate it. One woman bought six tartlets and told me they were for a book club that read crime novels but always ended up talking about neighbours, and that she had once tried to kiss a man while holding a pavlova and it had ended in tragedy. An old man with a cap that had seen carbon-something war asked if I sold custard squares and when I said not yet, he bought shortbread as if forgiving me. Lena turned up with her hair tucked under a cap because the wind refused to play nice, set up a plug-in coffee exterior to our stall, and began issuing flat whites like absolution. By mid-morning, I had the specific ache in my lower back that means you are alive and doing something that matters to you, and my hands had begun to smell permanently like lemon, sugar, and something like courage.

A woman with a lanyard that said HEALTH in capital letters came by and summarized our business plan by the way she kept her mouth soft while her eyes did their inspections. She asked me about temperature logs and holding times and whether I had a separate utensil for raw and cooked, and my heart did not climb into my throat because I had kept my promise to myself about control where there is control to be had. She told me her favourite dessert was jelly that pretends it’s grown-up, then bought a lamington and ate it like she had earned it. I tucked the first real stack of notes into the little tin we kept in a paper bag under the table and did not think too hard about whether this was security or superstition. Kahu ran crowd control for us with a clipboard and a smile that made people say yes to standing where he put them. He had made a pre-order list that made me want to cry from relief. He had also, I discovered later that afternoon, quietly told two teenagers who had turned feral in the queue that if they wanted to fight, they could fight him, and then made them hold our spare pegs while he told them they were hired.

After lunch, the sky remembered that weather in this country does not ask for permission. The marquee line shivered like a thing having a thought, and a single, fat drop landed on the corner of my chalkboard and smudged the word lemon into something that looked briefly like lonely. I wanted to call it an omen and then told myself to grow up. Then the wind came sideways, ambitious and rude, and lifted one leg of the gazebo with a smoothness that made my spine behave like a wire. The teacups rattled like a warning. The scones considered committing seppuku. Renee said, without raising her voice, “Hand me that spoon and the guy rope,” in a way that made me grin even while I ran for both. The beekeeper appeared at my elbow with a weight that had once been a brick and now was a solution. Between us, and the helpful man who had pegged us earlier and now materialized with a face like a farmer’s weather report, we battened the thing down with the confidence of people who had been blown around by bigger forces and were still here to tell stories.

It rained properly for seven minutes. Properly as in loudly and with an enthusiasm generally reserved for baptisms and late trains. We laughed in the way you do when you can hear your own ridiculousness and can’t do anything about it. People queued anyway; there is nothing more stubborn than a New Zealander in wet socks looking at a pastry. The shortbread kept its dignity. The lamingtons did what they always do and took on the weather like it was a personality trait. A child in a yellow raincoat that made them look like a lemon with opinions announced to the line at large that they were five and had eaten four lamingtons and their mother was not to be told, and seven strangers conspired to become complicit. At some point, someone put a hot hand around my upper arm and when I turned, Jules was there, rain squinting into their eyes, a beanie flattened against their head like a bird that had made peace with being wet. They had flown up in the morning because they had never learned the trick of resisting a good story that needed a pair of hands.

“Your tent is flirting with me,” they said. “It keeps lifting its skirt and showing me its ankles. I brought secret brownies. They’re for you and nobody else because I’m stingy about my love.”

“You’ve come all this way to bribe me,” I said, taking the Tupperware like I had never been given anything worth holding.

“I came to work,” they said, already taking a towel to the counter the way a good friend will put their hands on a thing without being asked. “And to tell you, because I remember how it feels, that you’re allowed to sit down for exactly five minutes right now and you will not die and the world will not catch fire.”

I sat. I did not die. The world continued to go on being too much and just enough. The brownies were obscene and restorative and tasted like dark chocolate married to salt in a way that made me consider writing a congratulations card. Jules ran interference with a woman who wanted to argue about whether the coconut should be toasted and parried her in two languages until she was smiling like a person who remembered she had come here because food makes mornings kind. We closed with the sort of relief that is not unmixed, because relief never is in lives like this. The last tartlet went to a girl with a skateboard under her arm who said lemon tasted like the part of the afternoon where you don’t have to be anywhere yet. The last scone went to a man in hi-vis who told us he’d been on night shift and didn’t trust the sun anymore, and we told him to trust butter instead and he said he’d give it a go.

At home that night, I counted money in little stacks as if numbers looked better in tidy groups and could be convinced of their manners. The take would not save us from the price of Auckland, but it would pay for next Saturday’s butter without my stomach becoming a knot that woke me at three. There were messages on the Back Steps page from people who wanted us at their school fundraisers and their office parties and their aunties’ birthdays. There were also two notes offering to tell me what I should have done differently, and I read them with the careful attention you give your own bad dreams, then told them to wait their turn and shut the door. I ran a bath that convinced me I could forgive my feet for their day, and I thought about the room at the hospice where Mrs. Healy had told me to salt my butter and eat even when I did not want to, and I ate anyway because ghosts are right about so many things. When I came out, the sign leaned against the wall like it had learned how to hold the room, and Kahu was asleep on the couch under a blanket Mrs. Kline had knit with a pattern she refused to reveal.

On Tuesday, there was a memorial in the hospice courtyard that smelled like lemon gel and cut grass and the hard sweetness of chrysanthemums. We put Mrs. Healy’s name on a sheet and the pen left a line that would be permanent in a book someone’s grandchild would hold in fifty years and say, Who was she. I spoke about scones and about a woman who would tell pain to sit down and have some tea if it wanted to stay. I said grief was a second language I had learned at the age when you are supposed to be learning your times tables and that I was tired and grateful in equal measure. The knitting ladies sat in a row like a choir and one of them sang a grace in a voice that had rubbed against a lot of air. Coco stood by the table where we put our plates and said, Take as much as you can carry, because food is the only appropriate inheritance we offer here. When we went back inside to the small bustle of the living, the hallway seemed to widen to let us through. I stood in the kitchen for a minute and put my hands on the bench and thought, as I always do in kitchens where the air has held grief, about what comes next that is small and doable.

After, business grew like a scruffy hedge that no council would discourage because it kept the wind off the neighbours. We made markets a habit and then, to our alarm, a reputation. People started saying we were their Saturday on the way to something else, which is a compliment you should write on your wall if you get it. I learned how to say no to the man who wanted me to bake his girlfriend a cake shaped like a jet ski, and yes to the nan in Sandringham who wanted me to show her mokopuna how to cut butter into flour without making it cross. Renee drove up every second weekend with a bag of lemons that made my back complain and a list of stories she had stored up like fruit in a pantry. She told me she had been in a house with a girl called Rua who had taught her how to braid bread with eyes shut, and in another house where she had taught a boy called Sam to make a roux that didn’t clump and he had cried when it did what it was supposed to because he was twenty-three and no one had believed him about anything else.

We started the Saturday classes with a budget like a thrift shop and a thirst like a drought. The hall in Whakatāne agreed to let us use the kitchen if we cleaned it better than we found it and left scones for the caretaker. In Auckland, the community centre unlocked the doors with the kind of generosity that comes from being used to your own heart being broken. The first class, a handful of women arrived with sharp elbows and sharper laughter, a man who had come because his grandkid had called him out on burning toast, two teenagers with chipped nail polish and eyes that did not leave the counter because they had learned that looking up could make you a target, and a lawyer who whispered to me that she ate biscuits in her car because she could not go home yet, sometimes, and is that a normal thing to admit to a stranger. We put flour on everyone’s hands because there is no way to keep flour off you that doesn’t involve lies. Mangling a dough together is both skill and rite, and watching people learn the texture of togetherness makes you feel like a thief who has been allowed to keep what she stole.

Renee and I developed a patter that would have been a double act if we had rehearsed it. She did the part where she told them to fold it like you meant the apology, and I did the part where I made them stop when their faces turned into the faces of their mothers. We handed people a knife who had not been handed anything sharp with trust, ever, and watched their shoulders come down when nothing bad happened and the butter behaved. We did a class at the hospice for the nurses and the women who had been there longer than the nurses, a class where salt was measured by sentence and sugar by story. Coco rolled pastry like she was smoothing people into their beds, and Mrs. Kline showed up with Beethoven in the harness only to direct traffic from a chair and tell everyone to watch their corners like a general. At the end of the first cycle, we stood on the back steps with paper plates and the kind of look between us that says we are doing a thing we meant to do and how ridiculous is that.

The practicalities behaved in their own messy way. I learned how to order butter wholesale without crying, how to asterisk my invoices so they would be seen by people whose inboxes were always on fire, how to speak to the woman in Council who held the power to deny me electricity with the respect due to a queen. Tasi built me a box that held the generator like a spoiled child and could be locked with a look. He came to the market one Saturday with his niece and bought two lamingtons and one scone and a coffee he pronounced good in the way you do when you love someone and are not going to lie to them. Kahu’s thesis came back with comments and he wrote them like a man who had been asked to sand a floor for the third time and decided to do it barefoot. He told me in the kitchen at midnight that sometimes he counted the chairs in our flat still, reflexive and unnecessary, and we laughed because neither of us needed the number anymore and that felt like winning something.

The letter turned up on a Wednesday that was tired of pretending to be Tuesday. It was in an envelope that had been addressed by someone with a long-standing love affair with cursive. The stamp was a wahine with hair like a wave. No return address. Inside, a single sheet of paper, blue-inked and careful, that began with my name and did not commit to any claims about me beyond that. It said, in a hand that had learned long ago how to be careful with its loops, that there had once been a woman in Ponsonby who baked quietly and hoped loudly, who had loved scones as if they could save people and believed that flour did not ask too many questions. It said the woman’s name as if I would recognize it and I did not, and then it said a second name, one my bones knew: Aunty Moana had kept other names for other people, and if I wanted to find the woman who had laughed at the gas oven like a miracle, I might try the block of flats on Norfolk Street where the man at Number Five collected bottle caps and left them on his windowsill in neat rows. It was not a promise. It was a nudge. Sometimes that is better. The signature at the bottom was a squiggle that belonged to someone who had not decided if she would be known.

I held the letter and thought about what it costs to go backwards. You don’t get to take the body you have now into a room where you were small. You must decide whether you are old enough to disappoint someone who might expect a child. I rang Jules and told them I had been given a puzzle in a country already full of puzzles, and they told me to remember that grief and joy both think they own the letterbox. I put the letter on the fridge behind the magnet that held the directions to the vineyard once and now held a list of who needed to be called about the next class. Then I called the number at the bottom, and it rang twice and then someone’s breath answered like a door opening in a house I had never lived in.

“Is this Nia,” she asked, in a voice that smelled like tea, “Nia who bakes.”

“It is,” I said, and the sound I made was not a laugh but had the honesty of one. “Who is this?”

“I’m someone who told your Renee she didn’t know what she was doing,” the woman said. “And then watched her do it. My name is very old and not interesting. My nephew lives downstairs and he watches your show repeatedly. I live upstairs and I watch my neighbours. If you want to come sit and watch me watch them, bring biscuits. If you don’t, then disregard. I am not above being ignored by the young.”

“I have never been good at ignoring instruction,” I said. “I can come Thursday. Is there anything you hate besides raisins?”

“I hate men who talk during the notices at the beginning of the movie,” she said. “And people who put fondant on cakes when what cake wants is frosting or nothing. Bring whatever you bring. The man at Number Five won’t answer the bell. He’s shy because he pretends he smoked once when he didn’t. Knock on the door to the right. I’m the one with too many plants and an opinion on everything.”

We went on Thursday. Kahu insisted on coming because he likes to meet the narrators of my life, and because he had a superstition about me walking into places with long hallways alone. Norfolk Street was that part of the city that remembers when it was more tired and less expensive. The block of flats had seen people arrive with suitcases and leave with debts and love. The stairwell smelled like damp carpet and curry and bleach that had done its best. On the landing, the bottle caps shone like small moons. A cat that had not signed a lease tried to trip us and then decided against it. A woman opened the door before we knocked and stood with her hand on her hip as if balancing the block with that one hinge in her body. Bo, she said her name was, Bo like a tie, Bo like a tilt of the head, Bo like a person who would keep a secret for the right reasons.

She had a couch that had held six lives. She had plants that had learned to grow toward a window that did not promise them anything. She had a photograph on a shelf of a woman with a scar by her eyebrow laughing at a girl holding a spoon like a joke. She made us tea and poured it high, and called me girl twice and child once and Kahu boy in a way that wasn’t diminishment, only a reminder that we were not as old as our worries. She told me she had known a man who had been in love with my mother once, long ago, and that this was not a story that ended with me at her door. She told me my mother had a way of leaving that looked like arriving because she always turned when she went, and sometimes that confused people into thinking she had stayed. She told me she had seen her ten years back on a bus going to Henderson with a bag of oranges and a look like she’d been told she could raise someone else’s child for a week.

“Do you want me to say she was good,” Bo asked, not unkind. “Do you want to hate her? Do you want me to tell you the shape of her mouth when she said your name because the truth is I don’t know if she ever did.”

“I want the part that is true,” I said. “And maybe a direction to face when I wake up at three.”

“The thing about mothers is they are people,” she said. “I know that’s blasphemy in some countries. She stood outside herself and didn’t always go back in. Renee went back in. Some people do. It is not noble. It is a choice. That is worse. You can’t blame a disease for it.”

We ate the biscuits I had brought, which had been meant to be shortbread and had turned into something else because I had been thinking too hard about the butter. Bo approved with the severity of a teacher and then leaned on her window sill to watch a man in a hat feed pigeons outside the dairy. She gave me two more names and the advice that if I got to a door and the person behind it wouldn’t look me in the face, I could look at their hands instead because hands don’t lie without telling on themselves. She told me if I found her, my mother, to not expect her to be grateful for being found, and if I didn’t, to stop thinking that failing to find a person is the same as failing to be one.

When we left, the gulls were arguing with a rubbish bin like the bin had started it. Kahu stood under the Norfolk pine that had done time as a Christmas tree in a hundred letterboxes and looked at me like he was asking if I was a house he could check the weatherboards on. I leaned against him because my legs weren’t sure who they were supposed to be at that hour. We went to Lena’s and stood behind the machine while she made three coffees with the concentration of a surgeon and pretended not to want to ask what the woman had said. I told her anyway, in pieces that had to be fitted together to make any sense. The world did not clap. It did the better thing and kept being itself. The afternoon turned into the kind where the clouds take up a strong opinion about who the sky belongs to, and I put my apron on and my list down and let my hands do what they know while my head went somewhere with a letter and a staircase and a photo and a woman who laughed as if failure could be baked out of flour if you loved it hard enough.

Business got busier and then got complicated in ways money has a way of inventing. An influencer with teeth like an advertisement came to a market and took photographs with our sign and my hands and announced to a world I was not in the habit of visiting that Back Steps was the new thing and that I seemed “authentically local, like a pie on a long bus trip.” Orders exploded in a way that would have looked perfect in a montage. I spent nights counting eggs and lost the thread on three conversations in a day because the part of my brain that tracks almond deliveries was shouting over the part that noticed people’s faces. Kahu said the words hire someone with the gravity some men use to say I love you and I pretended to ignore him and then did it, because he was right and because my shoulders had started to forget down. Our someone was a woman named Sila who smelled permanently of coriander, had a laugh that removed splinters, and could balance six plates on her forearm like a circus act while telling a story about a man who had come into her restaurant every Friday for a year to order the same thing and how when he died, she had made a plate for him anyway and put it on the corner table and let it get cold.

We let Back Steps be more than the stall. We made Wednesday nights at the hall something, too, a place where you could come with nothing and leave with a biscuit and maybe a recipe that would make you less afraid of yourself for ten minutes. We put a little jar by the door with a sign that said Give if you can, Take if you need, and a list of things we would trade baking for: a ride to the hospice, a guitar lesson for the kid with the skateboard, an hour of babysitting for the lawyer who needed a date with no law in it, a crochet lesson for Kahu because he had decided his thesis would be better if his fingers learned new patience. The jar behaved like a tide. Some weeks it was too full to lift. Some weeks it was empty and so were we and then someone would put two coins in it in a way that made me look away and think about jamming and generosity and how close they sit together in the mouth.

The night the power went out just as I was about to pull the tart shells and the kitchen filled with the kind of pitch that makes your bones hum, Jules lit three candles with the solemnity of a priest and said the sentence that heard the room take a breath: “We know how to bake by feel.” We finished by touch and by ear and stood on the back steps with a tray of tarts that had survived their own making and ate them with fingers and we remembered the old trick of licking sugar off our knuckles like we had invented it. When the lights came back on, everyone clapped in that automatic way people clap for electricity, as if apologizing to it for forgetting it is a miracle.

Things kept arriving. A letter from a school in Ōtara asking if I’d speak to a class about finding a life you don’t have to apologize for on Mondays. A message from a man in Australia who watched me on television while he fed his daughter at three a.m. and cried into her hair because his mother had made lamingtons for funerals and nobody did anymore where he was. A small, serious boy in a Star Wars T-shirt who came to the stall three weeks running with a coin exactly counted out and asked if I had ever thought of putting Milo in biscuit dough, and when I laughed and said we could try, he looked at me like I had given him a spare room. A woman with a shaved head who listened to me explain feijoa curd and then leaned across the table and told me in the voice you use when you’re brave that she hadn’t tasted anything in six months and maybe this would be the thing that brought her back to herself. It did. She came back the next week and cried so quietly about it that the world didn’t notice. We did.

When we went back to the vineyard for a charity event, I put my hand on the same tent pole just to see if it remembered me. It shivered like a friend you pass in a supermarket who’s trying to work out where you know each other from. The air had different names and the vines had grown like people who’d made decisions. Someone asked me to speak into a microphone and I did it like I hadn’t once been the girl who learned to make herself as small as a spoon. Later, standing by the car with the boot open and the night finally remembering to be dark, Arjun called from a place with snow in the corner of the window and told me he had a kitchen with a bench that didn’t wobble and a child who had decided bread was both food and toy. Maia sent a photo of a tray of fried bread her aunties had commandeered and said, Come over; and promised me a corner of a table to sit in while the women told me things I could not hear anywhere else.

On a Sunday afternoon that had decided to be a bowl rather than a plate, I sat on our own back step with my knees up and the city doing that low hum it does when it is not trying to impress anybody. Renee called from Whakatāne to tell me she’d burned a batch of jam and salvaged it with whiskey because life is nothing if not an argument with sugar. Kahu read me a paragraph of his thesis that made my breath do a trick and then pretended he had made me cry by accident. I licked a smear of curd off my thumb and looked at the line of ants investigating a crumb and thought, with the calm of a person who has had enough and not enough, that I had made a place that looked like me and that the world had decided, for the moment, to sit down. The gull on the fencepost opened its beak with malice and affection both and screamed in two notes that were almost, but not quite, my name. Somewhere in the pile of papers on the table behind me, a letter waited with a name on it that had always been mine. Somewhere down the street, a woman was hanging out washing and thinking about bread. Somewhere in a hall that smelled of varnish and old biscuits, someone would come on Saturday with their sharp elbows, and I would put flour on their hands, and together we would turn a bowl of ingredients into something you could eat, which has always been my favourite magic.

Chapter 9

By late winter, the city had decided to practice spring in little bursts, like a child testing the water with a toe and fleeing squealing. The morning light came early enough to catch me peering into mixing bowls like they had advice to give. Back Steps had settled into a rhythm that made sense to my ribs. Mondays were inventory and lists and accepting that butter cost what it cost no matter how nicely you asked. Tuesdays were deliveries and the kind of cleaning you do when you pretend you’re thinking about something else. Wednesdays were the hall classes that turned strangers into people who corrected each other’s flour measurements gently. Thursdays were for experimenting and burning a tray of something on purpose just to remember it happens. Fridays, Renee would arrive with a bag of lemons and a story, and Saturdays were the market, where we put on our best selves and then forgave each other when we were our second-best.

The school in Ōtara wrote again and did the thing I respect most in a request: they put times and names and a room number in the subject line. I said yes because I wanted to plant a seed in a building that knew about storms. Kahu pretended he wasn’t coming and then turned up in the doorway of my room with a stack of handouts he had designed that made the act of cutting butter look like a religious rite. We loaded the car with bowls and a bag of flour and two boxes of shortbread that had turned out odd because the oven had run hotter than usual and would therefore be radical and unforgettable. Cherry, having been spoken to sternly and bribed with a new air freshener that smelled more like laundry than lies, started obediently on the second try.

The classroom smelled exactly like every classroom I have ever loved and resented: whiteboard marker, too many backpacks, and somebody’s lunch trying to make friends. The kids were a mix of sharp elbows and practiced slouches, hoodies and hair gel and eyes with the old look. The teacher had the tolerance of a woman who had chosen this life on purpose and leaned on the back bench with her hands, not her hip, as if the room were a boat and she knew where to stand. We talked about baking like it was a language that would let you visit without embarrassment. I told them the secret of scones was to treat the dough like a creature you could startle and that the way you hold a knife tells the world how you’ve been held. A boy at the back who wore his hair like he had cut it himself asked if I was on that show, and when I admitted it, he grinned with too many teeth and said, “My nan hates you for what you said about jam,” and I told him to tell his nan that I would duel her with curd anytime and he laughed so hard he fell off his chair and then put himself back on it with dignity.

We rubbed butter into flour, and the room got quiet in that way that means everyone’s hands are occupied and the body remembers that stillness is not laziness. A girl with bitten nails pressed the dough with the heel of her hand and then looked at me like she’d been caught, and I said, “Gentler,” and her shoulders dropped three centimeters like I’d handed her a warmer coat. We took the trays to the canteen oven and the lunch lady, who had seen more chaos than any of us, told me she’d never liked scones because they were dry and I said, “Let’s make you a liar.” When the smell moved through the corridor, a man in a tie appeared at the door with the look of someone who often has to ask for money and is sometimes given it, and we fed him with the rest. The children ate and licked their thumbs and tried the word “sable” on their tongues and discovered it tasted like sand if you said it as if you didn’t respect French. When it was time to go, a girl with plaits counted out exact change for a lamington as if paying me gave her permission to enjoy it, and the teacher put her hand on my arm and said, “Come back,” and I said I would and meant it with my whole chest.

Back at the hall that evening, Jules leaned their hip against the bench and told a story about a café that had installed a slide instead of stairs because the owner thought fun and coffee should be adjacent and how within a week everyone had broken a tailbone and no one could tell if it was because of joy or bad design. They had decided to stay in Auckland for a while because Christchurch had been hard on them in a quiet, efficient way. There was a spare room in a flat in Kingsland where the shower was either arctic or hell and the neighbours played the saxophone at reasonable volumes, which somehow makes it worse. I wanted them closer the way you want someone else to turn up to a thing you’re nervous about without having to ask. We baked a batch of biscuits with Milo just because a boy had asked, and they came out the exact shade of school lost property, a taste like the quiet part of the afternoon on a carpet you used to hate. When we put them on a plate, Kahu stole one, pronounced it a cultural moment, and drafted a plan to letterbox the recipe around the neighbourhood like urgent political literature.

The letter from the council about the stall permit renewal arrived with a form attached that seemed to have been designed by a man who had never stepped outside. Somewhere between the sections titled HYGIENE PRACTICES and APPROVED WATER SOURCE ASSURANCES was a line that asked if I had access to inclement weather. I wrote yes because there was nowhere to write obviously. The health inspector came again, less stern this time, and admired our handwashing station like a friend. She told me someone had complained to her that our lamingtons were too generous and she had written back, “Find a better adjective,” which made me trust her for life. She also told me there’d been a butter shortage brewing like a quiet storm and advised me to spread my orders across suppliers in a way that suggested she had rescued more stalls than mine. I started buying butter like canned peaches in wartime and learned my wrists could carry more than I had given them credit for.

Bo phoned on a Wednesday when I was halfway through burning a batch of candied peel. The sound of her voice on my mobile made my spine think I was at a payphone. She had that calm that sometimes means there’s a sting at the end. “Your mother,” she said, dispensing with the part where we pretend this is casual gossip about a neighbour’s boyfriend, “has been seen at the op shop at the end of Richmond Road. Mondays. Helping with the bags no one wants to carry. She wears a scarf even when it’s warm. The girl who told me has the kind of memory I don’t argue with. If you go, don’t expect anything that tidy. And eat first, so you don’t behave like a person who hasn’t.”

I put the phone down and stood in the kitchen for longer than the situation warranted, but grief and hope both ask for stillness where you might give them movement. I told Kahu by leaving the kettle on and sitting at the table without touching a pencil. He made tea and didn’t ask if I was sure, because neither of us had the right to that question. I told Renee by sending her three lemon emojis and a picture of my left hand, the one with the knuckle I busted when I was thirteen and slammed it into a door that was not the problem. She replied with a single word—Steady—and a photo of her own hand with the scar by the eyebrow in the background. Jules arrived without knocking because doors mean different things to people who have had to hold them shut. They sat with me and made a list that had exactly six items: eat an actual meal, don’t go alone, bring very small biscuits, say your name out loud first, don’t rescue anyone, breathe even if it feels like you’re stealing air.

We went on a Monday because spell and habit are cousins. The op shop had the smell of old coats and the generosity of old ladies making do. The racks were packed with clothes that had seen better rooms and were willing to try again. A staff member with purple hair and a nose ring that said she’d probably volunteer at three different things told us that if we were here to dump a bag outside after hours, we could go straight to jail. I told her we were here to buy a teapot with a chip and she laughed like she was pleased to meet a liar. The scarves were in a basket, the kind you have to rustle to let them know you mean it. She was there, not as a miracle and not as an apparition, but as a woman folding jeans on a table the way you fold conversations you can’t have anymore. Her hair had that half-gone look bleach gives when it refuses to flatter you. The scarf was green with little white flowers like punctuation.

There weren’t trumpets. There was a carefulness. I said her name like it was a word I had checked the pronunciation of, and she looked up like a person who has learned to expect their name to be spoken when something needs doing. Her face did the computations you do when a stranger arrives carrying half of you in their eyes. She took a step and then a half-step back like the floor had changed levels and didn’t warn her. I held the bag of biscuits too tight and then loosened my hands because my fingers are not responsible for other people’s choices. We went outside because op shops are poor places to let a history unfold. On the street, we were two women with nothing to hide behind except a bin and the sky. She said, “Nia,” and I said, “Yes,” and that took the breath out of me more than anything else would have.

She told me she had left because she had thought it was kinder to stop trying when trying hurt. She told me there was a day she’d stood outside a house and counted to ten a hundred times and gone home without knocking because she didn’t have anything to put in the room that wouldn’t stain. She told me she had lied about where she was so long her mouth had worn a groove, and she was trying to wear a new one now. She said my name again like she was learning how old I’d become without the benefit of watching. I told her about Renee without giving away what wasn’t mine to tell. I told her about Mrs. Healy and the tent and the market and the hall and the gulls. I didn’t give her the small facts that would let her think she knew me without doing the work, like the way I sleep with one foot out of the duvet because it feels like a compromise. She told me she worked mornings and sometimes afternoons and always slept with the radio on. She did not promise me anything and I did not ask.

I gave her the biscuits because my hands needed to do something that wasn’t tuck a child into bed years too late. She laughed when she saw them because they were Milo and she had a story about leaving a boy with a mug and a spoon and a warning about ants and coming back to find him sleeping on his arm at the table with a moustache that would not wipe away. Then the laugh and the story turned back into the air, where they came from. She had a room, she said, off Ponsonby Road, a place you can hear other people’s lives through a wall, and it kept her honest. She asked if this was where I wanted to stop or start, and I said I didn’t know, which was true. We agreed to pick a day and an hour and not to give it too much shape. On the way home, I spoke to the wind, because it would not tell anyone, and told it that I had done the brave thing without knowing if I would get a reward. It told me, in that way that weather talks, that the reward is a different question.

The next weeks bled like a nose you forgot to tilt your head forward for. We met once in a café where the seats were bolted down as if someone had tried to leave with a bench before. We drank tea and talked around the edges. She had my eyelashes and a way of not finishing a sentence that made me want to pick it up and put it back in her mouth, which I didn’t, because I am not a surgeon and the wound didn’t belong to me. She told me a story about the time she had saved a cake by pretending she always meant for it to be a trifle. I told her I make curd like it’s a way to smuggle summer into winter. We parted like colleagues at the end of a shift, polite without being false. I went home and made marmalade until my kitchen looked like a science experiment, and when it set, I wrote her name on a jar and put it at the back of the cupboard and told myself she would ask for it one day and also that she might not.

In the middle of all that, life kept insisting on itself rudely. Kahu defended his thesis on a Wednesday morning with a fever that would have made a wiser man reschedule. He wore a shirt I recognized from a party we’d gone to where the chips had been stingy and people had been stingier. He stood in a room with bad carpet and explained the price of water and the ways it gets into a body and the language we use to pretend we don’t know who it belongs to, and he did not once use the word journey even when they gave him an opening the size of a paddock. He came out with a look on his face like he had been holding up a roof and now someone else had finally got a hand under it. We went straight from the university to the market and made the kind of scones that get confused for communion, and he told everyone who would listen that the planet had not been saved by his document and that was not the point.

Mrs. Kline had a fall on a Thursday, the kind that looks small until the next morning. She left me a note under my door in handwriting that wobbled but made it across the page like a determined canoe. It said, in the way a general might tell you to fix your hair, that she’d had a disagreement with the rug and the rug had won and could I please go to the dairy and tell Mr. Singh to let her pay him later for the eggs because she did not intend to stop making pancakes at her age just to please time. I went up. Beethoven blinked at me with the disdain of a creature who has never fallen, then put his paw on my knee as if to remind me of my role on this earth. We made pancakes together, the kind with too much baking soda because she insists it keeps you upright, and she told me about a girl who’d come to her door at midnight seven years ago crying and how she’d made that girl sit down and eat toast and then washed the girl’s hair like it was a spell. It was new information and old. She told me she had written to a cousin in Napier who once knew how to find a man in a pub in Tauranga, because that’s how you find people in this country, and did I want her to put out the word or was that me taking too much in both hands. I said to put out the word. She nodded and said, “Good girl,” and the words landed on my bones like a blanket.

Sila took to Back Steps like she’d been waiting to be told where to put the trays. She organized the Esky with the ruthless thoughtfulness of someone who had raised three children and one teenager who wasn’t hers on a budget that would make anyone else mean. She told me I didn’t charge enough for the tartlets and I told her to stop being my father, and she looked at me like I had revealed more than I meant to and then told me I was doing the math wrong and I knew that she was right so I printed new cards with numbers that made me feel like a thief and then remembered that paying rent does not make you a villain. Sila brought her sister one Saturday, a nurse with hands that could hypnotize a child, and between them they moved the queue so gracefully people thought they were dancing and put money in the jar.

Wind found us again the day we were invited to set up on a corner of the farmers’ market where the fancy stalls were. The vendor who sold very good salt with words on the packet came over and introduced herself without a single insult, which made me suspicious. We had just got the gazebo to stop behaving like a kite when the sky changed clothes. The stall ropes sang like people who don’t know the words and the air moved through the vines like gossip. The wind took the chalkboard and sent it three stalls down. Jules chased it and came back with it under their arm, hair in their eyes, yelling that the wind had asked for a discount and they had told it to get bent. We held the tent down with everything that wasn’t nailed to the soil. The beekeeper showed up with more weights because apparently he lives for bad weather. A teenage boy from the stall that sells apples put his shoulders under one leg of our gazebo and stood there for seven minutes and never mentioned it later, which is how you know someone has been raised to think being useful is a language.

After the storm, the air felt like a drunk who had decided to apologize. The customers came back in that way where they pretend they weren’t waiting across the road calculating the risk of damp coconut. We sold out of shortbread because everyone in a five-kilometre radius had decided they were owed sugar for surviving. I put a pair of lamingtons aside because a boy had come early with exact change and asked me to save them, and when he came back three hours later with a bandage on his knee and a look like he’d lost a race with a kerb, I handed them over as if we had planned this together. He told me he had stood in the rain because lamingtons taste better if your socks are wet, and I told him I would put that on a T-shirt and he said to make sure I credited him, and we shook on it.

The television people called about a segment on small businesses with not enough money and too much heart. I told them to bring their own extension cord. Poppy came along with a lanyard even though we weren’t on her show anymore because she had caught the disease and couldn’t stop being helpful. She pointed their cameras at Sila, at the Esky, at the jar by the door that said Give if you can, Take if you need, and a microphone at my mouth that tried to make me say things I didn’t mean. I talked about butter and grief and why toast is sometimes the only dinner that does the job, and then they filmed a slow shot of honey dripping off a spoon as if it were a metaphor and I tried not to roll my eyes. When I got home, there was a message from a woman in Balclutha with a photo of her kitchen and a paragraph about her mother’s hands and the way her mother had taught her to count in a language the radio never used. She had never thought to put feijoa in curd, she said. She had always thought it would taste like an argument. She tried it and said it tasted like her auntie telling her to be brave and not look foolish. I wrote back and told her that was sometimes the same thing.

On a Sunday, I went to the hall in Whakatāne because I had promised and because promises are a kind of axle. Renee was there with the oven that has opinions and a class that had signed up because word had gotten around that we were rude about fondant. There were four aunties at the bench with the competence of women who have fed boats and funerals, and a boy with a breathless look who wanted to fold pain into pastry and didn’t say that aloud. We made a pie that didn’t leak and a biscuit that did, and we decided the tidy thing was not always the goal. An old man came to the door with a cardboard tray of oranges from a tree that had forgiven him, and he put it down and said, “For the girls,” and I didn’t correct him. After, I sat on the steps out back with Renee and told her about my mother like I was describing weather. She put her hand on the back of my neck and squeezed once like a mechanic testing a bolt. She said, “If she comes, let her sit. You know how. If she goes, let her go. You know how,” and then she told me about a woman named Tia who had taken a bus to Gisborne and met a man at a fish and chip shop and decided, over battered tarakihi, to stay one more day, and the next, and then two decades later to come home and teach a class on how not to waste your life pretending fat is a sin.

That week, the woman with the shaved head came back for more tartlets. This time she brought her mother, whose head still had hair, and they stood together in front of the table and told me that taste had returned like a memory out of order. They bought scones and then sat on the curb because the benches were full and ate in a silence that was not grim. When they left, the mother squeezed my fingers and told me I’d done a kindness no doctor had managed, and I thought she overestimated me wildly and decided not to correct her because sugar can do better things when it’s not interrupted.

We had a night in the hall where we tried to make kouign-amann because sometimes you need to look God in the eye. We drew butter into flour and the room smelled like a church for people who love a challenge. The first tray was a crime, and we ate it to hide the evidence. The second tray sang the right note, and the room made that small moan people do when dopamine knows it has a role. Jules leaned on the counter in the afterwards and said, “Do we remember how to be small?” and I said, “We are already small,” and they said, “Not like that,” and I said, “Ask me again when my mother sings to me or doesn’t,” and they nodded like I had told them the weather report for the kind of day that has both beach and windscreen wipers.

The day of the meeting I did not call a meeting, I put on a clean T-shirt and a jumper without sugar welded to it and wore my hair down because I wanted to look like a person who had made choices and not just been chosen by the kitchen. We met at a laundromat because the café felt like too much and the park felt like a trick. The washing machines made their fluent arguments, and the smell of detergent did its best to tidy what it could. She came in with a plastic bag of clothes she didn’t put down. She looked better than the first time, which is to say she looked like she had slept a little and had not argued with the mirror. We put coins in machines and watched fabric try to forgive sins. She asked me if I wanted to know the names of men who had tried to be father enough for a day. I said no because I couldn’t keep them and she nodded like I’d passed a test she hadn’t meant to set. She told me about a job she had for a few months where she washed sheets in a hotel and the way she learned not to imagine the lives that had happened in them because she would drown. I told her about the hospice without saying the word dying and she understood without needing me to be brave.

When the spin cycle hit that part where it feels like the world is going to leave the bench, she said, “I am not good,” and I said, “Neither am I,” and then we both corrected ourselves, because “good” is a word that has been used against us for too long. She said, “I am trying,” and I said, “Me too,” which felt like giving each other a handshake in a dark room. When we parted, she touched my arm the way you touch a cat you don’t know yet, light, and asked if I would send a photo of my stall because she wanted to see the sign. I sent it on the way home. She replied with a picture of a plate with three scones on it that were not mine and a caption that just said, Second try, and I sat in the car with the engine off and cried for four minutes with the clean grief of someone who has been waiting for a sentence exactly that length.

Paperwork began to wear me out in new ways. The grant for the classes needed four references and a budget that made sense even in daylight. Poppy wrote one like a person used to being generous with stationery. The nurse from the hall wrote one that made me blush in the kitchen when I read it alone. Tasi wrote one that spoke about me as if I were an engine that could be tuned and he was profoundly impressed by the torque. The fourth came from the school in Ōtara and it said, without weeping, that the scones had been soft and so had the way I had spoken to the kids and that these are related, which is the sort of sentence that should be allowed to be stapled to your person as a charm. I sent the packet off with a breath and a joke in the subject line because sometimes you can bribe the universe with tone.

A woman named Lani came to the stall and asked if she could bring her Twins—capital T—to a class. She said it with the delicate smile of someone who has fielded too many jokes about twins and is not here for your comedy. The boys turned up with haircuts that had been negotiated and the carefulness of kids who have been told they are a handful and have decided to become one. We set them up at the end of the bench and I gave them the job of zesting lemons because it involves knives and adults are cowards. They zested with the concentration of surgeons and the kindness of people who split the good part of a biscuit without being asked. On the way out, one of them put fifty cents in the jar and the other took a fifty-cent piece out. Lani pretended not to see and then asked me on the phone later if that was stealing and I said it was balance and she said she had been raised strict and I said to raise them kind.

Sila got a call about her sister’s baby and left a trail of tea towels and promises. She came back with photos that made us all fall over with the right kind of envy. We sent a box of scones and a jar of curd to a hospital ward where a new life had entered a room that smelled like sanitizer and sweat and someone swearing love through their teeth. In the group chat for the hall classes, a woman sent a picture of her first pie that didn’t slump, and we all told her she was a god. The boy with the skateboard turned up with his mother, who bought a tart as if rewarding him for not getting detention, and then told me quietly she had been learning to bake from YouTube because sometimes talking to a person was too much, and I told her to come to class and stand at the back and leave if it was loud and she said she had been hoping I would tell her that.

On the day the grant email arrived, I was in the car outside the wholesaler calculating the per-scone cost of cream like I was being paid to do math. The subject line had the name of the council and then the word Congratulations, which should come with a medical warning. I read it twice and then out loud to the steering wheel, and then I sent a message to Renee which was only exclamation points and a lemon, and she replied with a photo of her hands and the elbow scar and a loaf of bread she had decided to teach the girls on Saturday because now we could afford more flour. I drove home with butter in the boot and hope on the passenger seat and got a parking ticket I refused to hate because sometimes you have to let the city take a coin out of your pocket and call it a tax for being alive.

That night, the community centre hall filled with people who had smelled something happen. We put a sign on the door that said FREE BISCUITS, FUNDING JOY, and the room did the thing where it grows another wall to make room. The knitting ladies came with their elbows and their opinions. The school teacher brought the boy who had accused me of treason against jam. The aunties from Whakatāne arrived with a plastic container of fried bread like a bribe. The beekeeper turned up with a jar labelled most polite this season. The health inspector came in civvies and refused to talk about hygiene more than once and then ate a lamington like she had been practicing not to for a month. Jules stood by the urn and poured tea with a flourish that made people put money in the jar even though it was a free biscuits night.

I told them the grant had come through and that we could pay the hall without me having to decide whether butter or electricity mattered more. I told them we were going to run a class on Tuesdays for anyone who had ever been told off for making crumbs, and that the rule would be that if one person came we would teach one person and if thirty came we would teach thirty and if no one came we would sit in the kitchen and make biscuits for the Thursday drop-offs. People clapped and then began to mill around like molecules learning a new structure. Mrs. Kline sat in a chair near the door so she could direct traffic, Beethoven in his harness like a prisoner who had charmed his guard. Bo came in late with the kind of entrance you make when you know the room will make a space for you and told me she had written down the name of a woman who might tell me something I hadn’t asked the right question for. I took the paper and put it between my fingers the way you do with a wafer at a church you attend sometimes.

When the night was ebbing and the dishes were piled in a way that would make tomorrow yell my name, I went outside to the back steps, where the air knows you. The city had chosen to be quiet, which happens so rarely you should sit when it does. The gull on the fencepost had three feathers out of order and did not care. I thought about the tiny seam between acts of love and acts of labour. I thought about my mother’s second-try scones and the way I had not yet decided if I would bring her a jar of curd or make her ask. I thought about Mrs. Healy and the way Coco’s voice had held me in the doorway of that room, and about the way the hospice had loaned us a projector like it was the most normal thing. I thought about the boy with the exact change and the girl with the bitten nails and the twins who didn’t steal, they balanced, and about how every room I had stood in had taught me to count chairs until I could stop.

Inside, someone yelled my name in a tone that meant there was either an emergency or a cake that had turned out prettier than expected. I stood up, felt a pull in the back of my calf that told me I was human and not built entirely from stubbornness, and went in. The next morning there would be a meeting with a woman at a bank who would speak to me like I was a ship in shallow water and offer me a loan with teeth. There would be a letter to write to a boy in Dunedin who wanted to know how to bake without waking his father. There would be a shopping list for butter and lemons and the green cord that goes on the gazebo that always disappears, and a call to Tasi to ask if the new sound Cherry was making was a joke or a threat. There would be all the small practical magic that keeps a life from coming apart at its seams. For now, the room put its hand on my back and moved me where I needed to be. For now, the biscuits cooled. For now, the gull shrieked two notes that didn’t sound like my name and I decided I didn’t mind.
